div.p: As it was acted at the private house in black friars with great applause.
London printed for Andrew Pennycuicke, one of the actors, in the year 1659.

list.item: Sir John Lacy son to lord Lacy.
Luke brother to sir John rich.

row.cell: Their sons, prentices, to sir John rich.

div.head: To the truly noble and virtuous lady Ann, countess of Oxford.
div.p:
In that age when wit and learning were outconquered by injury, and violence; this poem was the object of love and commendations, it being composed by an infallible pen, and censured by an unerring auditory. In this epistle I shall not need to make an apology: for plays in general by exhibiting their antiquity and utility, in a word they are mirrors or glasses which none but deformed faces, and fouler consciences fear to look into. The encouragement I had to
prefer this dedication to your powerful protection proceeds from the universal fame of the deceased author, who (Although he composed many) writ none amiss, and this may justly be ranked amongst his best. I have redeemed it from the teeth of time, by committing of it to the press, but in more imploring your patronage, I will not slander it with my praises, it is commendations enough to call it massingers, if it may gain your allowance and pardon; I am highly gratified, and desire only to wear the happy title of,

sp.speaker: Goldwire
sp.l: The ship is safe in the pool then?

sp.speaker: Tradewell.
sp.l: And makes good,
In her rich fraught, the name she bears, the Speedwell:
My master will find it, for on my certain knowledge
For every hundred that he ventured in her
She hath returned him five.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: And it comes timely,
For besides a payment on the nail for a manor
Late purchased by my master, his young daughters
Are ripe for marriage.

sp.speaker: Tradewell.
sp.l: Who? Nan, and Moll.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: Mistress Anne and Mary, and with some addition,
Or 'tis more punishable in our house
Then scandalum magnatum.

sp.speaker: Tradewell
sp.l: 'Tis great pity
Such a gentleman as my master for that title
His being a citizen, cannot take from him,
Hath no male heir to inherit his estate,
And keep his name alive.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: The want of one
Swells my young mistresses, and their madam mother
With hopes above their birth, and scale. Their dreams are
Of being made countesses, and they take state
As they were such already. When you went
To the Indies, there was some shape and proportion
Of a merchant's house in our family, but since
My master, to gain precedency for my mistress
Above some elder merchants wives, was knighted
'Tis grown a little court, in bravery,
Variety of fashions, and those rich ones:
There are few great ladies going to a masque
That do outshine ours in their everyday habits.

sp.speaker: Tradewell.
sp.l: 'Tis strange my master in his wisdom can
Give the reins to such exorbitancy.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: He must,
Or there's no peace nor rest for him at home;
I grant his state will bear it, yet he's censured
For his indulgence, and for sir John frugal
By some styled sir John prodigal.

sp.speaker: Tradewell.
sp.l: Is his brother
Mr. Luke frugal living?

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: Yes, the more
His misery, poor man.

sp.speaker: Tradewell.
sp.l: Still in the counter?

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: In a worser place. He was redeemed from the hole,
To live in our house in hell: since his base usage
Considered, 'tis no better. My proud lady
Admits him to her table, marry ever
beneath the salt, and there he sits the subject
Of her contempt and scorn; and dinner ended,
His courteous nieces find employment for him
Fitting an under-prentice, or a footman,
And not an uncle.

sp.speaker: Tradewel.
sp.l: I wonder, being a scholar well read, and travelled,
The world yielding means for men of such desert,
He should endure it.
sp.stage: Enter Stargaze, lady, Anne, Marry, Millescent, in several postures, with looking-glasses at their girdles.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: He does, with a strange patience; and to us
The servants so familiar, nay humble.
I'll tell you, but I am cut off. Look these
Like a citizen's wife and daughters?

sp.speaker: Tradewel.
sp.l: In their habits
They appear other things; but what are the motives
Of this strange preparation?

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: The young wagtails
Expect their suitors. The first, the son and heir
Of the lord lady, who needs my master's money,
As his daughter does his honour. The second Mr. plenty,
A rough hewn gentleman, and newly come
To a great estate, and so all aids of art
In them's excusable.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: You have done your parts here:
To your study, and be curious in the search
Of the nativities.

sp.speaker: Tradewel.
sp.l: Methinks the mother,
As if she could renew her youth, in care,
Nay curiosity to appear lovely,
Comes not behind her daughters.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: Keeps the first place,
And though the church-book speak her fifty, they
That say she can write thirty, more offend her,
Then if they taxed her honesty: tother day
A tenant of hers, instructed in her humour,
But one she never saw, being brought before her,
For saying only, good young mistress help me
to the speech of your lady-mother, so far pleased her,
That he got his lease renewed for't.

sp.speaker: Tradewell.
sp.l: How she bristles:
Prithee observe her.

sp.speaker: Millescent.
sp.l: As I hope to see
A country knights son and heir walk bare before you
When you are a countess, as you may be one
When my master dies, or leaves trading; and I continuing
Your principal woman, take the upperhand
Of a squire's wife, though a justice, as I must
By the place you give me, you look now as young
As when you were married.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I think I bear my years well.

sp.speaker: Millescent.
sp.l: Why should you talk of years? Time hath not ploughed
One furrow in your face; and were you not known
The mother of my young ladies, you might pass
For a virgin of fifteen.

sp.speaker: Tradewell.
sp.l: Here's no gross flattery:
Will she swallow this?

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: You see she does, and glibly.

sp.speaker: Millescent.
sp.l: You never can be old, wear but a masque
Forty years hence, and you will still seem young
In your other parts: what a waste is here? O Venus?
That I had been born a King! and here a hand
To be kissed ever; pardon my boldness, madam:
Then, for a leg and foot you will be courter
When a great grandmother.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: These indeed, wench, are not
So subject to decayings as the face,
Their comeliness lasts longer.

sp.speaker: Milliscent.
sp.l: Ever, ever:
Such a rare featured, and proportioned madam
London could never boast of.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Where are my shoes.

sp.speaker: Milliscent.
sp.l: Those that your ladyship gave order
Should be made of the Spanish perfumed skins.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: The same.

sp.speaker: Milliscent.
sp.l: I sent the prison-bird this morning for 'em,
But he neglects his duty.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: He is grown
Exceeding careless.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: And begins to murmur
At our commands, and sometimes grumbles to us,
He is forsooth our uncle.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: He is your slave,
And as such use him.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Willingly, but he's grown
Rebellious madam.
sp.stage: Enter Luke, with shoes, garters and roses.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: Nay like hen, like chicken.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I'll humble him.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: There he comes sweating all over,
He shows like a walking frippery.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Very good sir,
Were you drunk last night, that you could rise no sooner
With humble diligence to do what my daughters,
And woman did command you.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Drunk, an't please you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Drunk, I said, sirrah. Darest thou in a look
Repine, or grumble? thou unthankful wretch,
Did our charity redeem thee out of prison,
Thy patrimony spent, ragged, and lousy.
When the sheriff's basket, and his broken meat
Were your festival exceedings, and is this
So soon forgotten?

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: I confess I am
Your creature madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: And good reason why
You should continue so.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Who did new cloth you?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Admitted you to the dining-room?

sp.speaker: Milliscent.
sp.l: Allowed you a fresh bed in the garret?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Or from whom
Received you spending money?

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: I owe all this
to your goodness, madam: for it you have my prayers,
The beggar's satisfaction; all my studies,
(Forgetting what I was, but withal duty
Remembering what I am) are how to please you.
And if in my long stay I have offended,
I ask your pardon. Though you may consider,
Being forced to fetch these from the old exchange,
These from the tower, and these from Westminster,
I could not come much sooner.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: Here was a walk
To breathe a footman.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: 'Tis a curious fan.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: These roses will show rare; would 'twere in fashion
That the garters might be seen too.

sp.speaker: Milliscent.
sp.l: Many ladies
That know they have good legs, wish the same with you:
Men that way have th'advantage.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: I was with the lady,
And delivered her the satin
For her gown, and velvet for her petticoat,
This night she vows she'll pay you.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: How I am bound
To your favour m. Luke.

sp.speaker: Milliscent.
sp.l: As I live, you will perfume all rooms you walk in.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Get your fur,
You shall pull 'em on within.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: That servile office
Her pride imposes on him.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: Tradewell.

sp.speaker: Tradewell.
sp.l: My master calls. We come sir.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: What have you brought there?

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.l: The cream of the market, provision enough
To serve a garrison. I weep to think on't.
When my master got his wealth, his family fed
On roots, and livers, and necks of beef on sundays.
But now I fear it will be spent in poultry.
Butcher's meat will not go down.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Why, you rascal, is it at
Your expense? what cooks have you provided?

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.l: The best of the city. They have wrought at my
Lord mayors.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Fie on 'em, they smell of Fleet-lane, and pie-corner.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: And thinks the happiness of man's life consists
In a mighty shoulder of mutton.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I'll have none
Shall touch what I shall eat, you grumbling cur,
But Frenchmen and Italians; they wear satin,
And dish no meat but in silver.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.l: You may want, though,
A dish or two when the service ends.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Leave prating,
I'll have my will; do you as I command you.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: You were with plenty?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: And what answer
Returned the clown?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Clown sir! he is transformed,
And grown a gallant of the last edition;
More rich than gaudy in his habit, yet
The freedom, and the bluntness of his language
Continues with him. When I told him that
You gave him caution, as he loved the peace,
And safety of his life, he should forbear
To pass the merchant's threshold, until you
Of his two daughters had made choice of her
Whom you designed to honour as your wife.
He smiled in scorn.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: In scorn?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: His words confirmed it,
They were few, but to this purpose; tell your master,
Though his lordship in reversion were now his,
It cannot awe me. I was born a freeman,
And will not yield in the way of affection
Precedence to him. I will visit 'em,
Though he sat porter to deny my entrance.
When I meet him next I'll say more to his face.
Deliver thou this, then gave me a piece
To help my memory, and so we parted.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: Where got he this spirit.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: At the academy of valour,
Newly erected for the institution
Of elder brothers. Where they are taught the ways,
Though they refuse to seal for a duellist,
How to decline a challenge. He himself
Can best resolve you.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: You sir?

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: What with me sir?
How big you look? I will not lose a hat
To a hair's breadth, move your beaver, I'll move mine,
Or if you desire to prove your sword, mine hangs
As near my right hand, and will as soon out, though I keep
Not a fencer to breathe me, walk into Moorfields,
I dare look on your Toledo. Do not show
A foolish valour in the streets, to make
Work for shopkeepers, and their clubs, 'tis scurvy,
And the women will laugh at us.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: You presume
On the protection of your hinds.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: I scorn it:
Though I keep men I fight not with their fingers,
Nor make it my religion to follow
The gallants fashion, to have my family
Consisting in a footman, and a page,
and those two sometimes hungry. I can feed these,
And clothe 'em too, my gay sir.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: What a fine man
Hath your tailor made you?

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: 'Tis quite contrary,
I have made my tailor, for my clothes are paid for
As soon as put on, a sin your man of title
Is seldom guilty of, but heaven forgive it.
I have other faults too very incident
To a plain gentleman. I eat my venison
With my neighbours in the country, and present not
My pheasants, partridges, and grouse to the usurer,
Nor ever yet paid brokage to his scrivener.
I flatter not my mercer's wife, nor feast her
With the first cherries, or pelcods, to prepare me
Credit with her husband, when I come to London.
The wool of my sheep, or a score or two of fat oxen
In Smithfield, give me money for my expenses.
I can make my wife a jointure of such lands too; as are not encumbered, no annuity
Or statue lying on 'em. This I can do
And it please your future honour, and why therefore
You should forbid my being a suitor with you
My dulness apprehends not.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: This is bitter.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: I have heard you sir, and in my patience shown
To much of the Stoics. But to parley further,
Or answer your gross jeers would write me coward.
This only thy great grandfather was a butcher,
And his son a grazier,
Thy sire constable of the hundred, and thou the first of your dunghill, created gentleman
Now you may come on sir, you, and your thrashers.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: Stir not on your lives.
This for the graziers, this for the butcher.They fight

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: So sir.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: I'll not stand idle, draw my little rapier
against your bum blades. I'll one, by one dispatch you.
Then house this instrument of death, and horror.
sp.stage: Enter sir John, Luke, Goldwire, Tradewell.

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.l: Beat down their weapons. My gate ruffian's hall:
What insolence is this?

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Noble sir Maurice,
Worshipful Mr. plenty.

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.l: I blush for you,
Men of your quality expose your same
To every vulgar censure. This at midnight
After a drunken supper in a tavern,
(No civil man abroad to censure it)
Had shown poor in you, but in the day, and view
Of all that pass by, monstrous

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: Very well sir;
You look for this defence.

sp.speaker: Lacte.
sp.l: 'Tis thy protection,
But it will deceive thee.

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.l: Hold, if you proceed thus
I must make use of the next justice's power,
And leave persuasion. And in plain terms tell you

sp.stage: Enter lady, Anne, Marry, and Milliscent.
sp.l: Neither your birth, sir Maurice, nor your wealth,
Shall privilege this riot. See whom you have drawn
To be spectators of it? can you imagine
It can stand with the credit of my daughters,
To be the argument of your swords? Ith' street too?
Nay ere you do salute, or I give way,
To any private conference, shake hands
In sign of peace. He that drawsiback parts with
My good opinion. This is as it should be.
Make your approaches, and if their affection
Can sympathize with yours, they shall not come
On my credit beggars to you. I will hear
What you reply within.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: May I have the honour
To support you lady.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: I know not what's supporting,
but by this fair hand, glove and all, I love you.
sp.stage: To him enter Hoyst, penury, fortune.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: You are come with all advantage. I will help you
To the speech of my brother.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: Have you moved him for us?

sp.speaker: Luke
sp.l: With the best of my endeavours, and I hope.
You'll find him tractable.

sp.speaker: Penury.
sp.l: Heaven grant he prove so.

sp.speaker: Hoyst.
sp.l: Howe'er I'll speak my mind.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Do so m. Hoyst.
Go in. I'll pay my duty to this lord,
And then I am wholly yours. Heaven bless your honour.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Your hand Mr. Luke, the world's much changed with you
Within these few months; than you were the gallant:
No meeting at the horse-race, cocking, hunting,
Shooting, or bowling, at which Mr. Luke
Was not a principal gamester, and companion
For the nobility.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: I have paid dear
For those follies, my good lord, and 'tis but justice
That such as soar above their pitch, and will not
Be warned by my example, should like me
Share in the miseries that wait upon't.
Your honour in your charity may do well
Not to upbraid me with those weaknesses
Too late repented.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: I nor do, nor will;
And you shall find I'll lend a helping hand
To raise your fortunes: how deals your brother with you?

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Beyond my merit, I thank his goodness for't.
I am a freeman, all my debts discharged,
Nor does one creditor undone by me
Curse my loose riots. I have meat and clothes,
Time to ask heaven remission for what's past;
Cares of the world by me are laid aside,
my present poverty's a blessing to me;
And though I have been long, I dare not say
I ever lived till now.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: You bear it well;
Yet as you wish I should receive for truth
What you deliver, with that truth acquaint me
With your brother's inclination. I have heard
In the acquisition of his wealth, he weighs no:
Whose ruins he builds upon.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: In that report
Wrongs him, my lord. He is a citizen,
And would increase his heap, and will not lose
What the law gives him. Such as are worldly wise
Pursue that tract, or they will never wear scarlet.
But if your honour please to know his temper,
You are come opportunely. I can bring you
Where you unseen shall see, and hear his carriage
Towards some poor men, whose making or undoing
Depend upon his pleasure.
sp.stage: A table, count book, standish, chair and stools set out,

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: To my wish,
I know no object that could more content me.

sp.stage: Enter sir John, Hoyst, fortune, penury, Goldwire.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: What would you have me do? reach me a chair.
When I lent my moneys I appeared an angel;
But now I would call in mine own, a devil.

sp.speaker: Hoyst.
sp.l: Were you the Devil's damn, you must stay till I have it.
For as I am a gentleman,
sp.stage: Enter Luke placing the lord Lacy,

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: There you may hear all.

sp.speaker: Hoyst.
sp.l: I pawned you my land for the tenth part of the value,
Now, cause I am a gamester, and keep ordinaries,
And a livery punk, or so, and trade not with
the money-mongers wives, not one will be bound for me:
'Tis a hard case, you must give me longer day
Or I shall grow very angry.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Fret, and spare not.
I know no obligation lies upon me
With my honey to feed drones. But to the purpose,
How much owes penury?

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: Two hundred pounds:
His bond three times since forfeited.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Is it sued?

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: Yes sir, and execution out against him

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: For body and goods.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: For both, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: See it served.

sp.speaker: Penury.
sp.l: I am undone; my wife and family.
Must starve for want of bread.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: More infidel thou
In not providing better to support 'em.
What's fortune's debt?

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: A thousand, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: An estate
For a good man. You were the glorious trader,
Embraced all bargains; the main venturer
In every ship that launched forth; kept your wife
As a lady, she had her coach, her choice
Of summer-houses, built with other men's moneys
Took up at interest, the certain road
To Ludgate in a citizen. Pray you acquaint me
How were my thousand pounds employed?

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: Insult not
On my calamity, though being a debtor,
And a slave to him that lends, I must endure it.
Yet hear me speak thus much in my defence;
Losses at sea, and those sir, great, and many,
By storms, and tempests, not domestical riots
In soothing my wife's humour, or mine own,
Have brought me to this low ebb.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Suppose this true;
what is't to me? I must, and will have my money,
Or I'll protest you first, and that done have
The statute made for bankrupts served upon you.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: 'Tis in your power, but not in mine to shun it.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Not as a brother, sir, but with such duty
As I should use unto my father, since
Your charity is my parent, give me leave
To speak my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: What would you say?

sp.speaker: Luke
sp.l: No word, sir,
I hope shall give offence; nor let it relish
Of flattery, though I proclaim aloud:
I glory in the bravery of your mind,
To which your wealths a servant. Not that riches
Is or should be contemned, it being a blessing
Derived from heaven, and by your industry
Pulled down upon you; but in this dear, sir,
You have many equals: such a man's possessions
Extend as far as yours, a second hath
His bags as full; a third in credit flies
As high in the popular voice: but the distinction
And noble difference by which you are
Divided from 'em, is, that you are styled
Gentle in your abundance, good in plenty,
And that you feel compassion in your bowels
Of others miseries (I have found it, sir,
Heaven keep me thankful for't) while they are cursed
As rigid and inexorable.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: I delight not
To hear this spoke to my face.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: That shall not grieve you,
Your affability, and mildness clothed
In the garments of your debtors breath
Shall everywhere , though you strive to conceal it
Be seen, and wondered at, and in the act
With a prodigal hand rewarded. Whereas such
As are born only for themselves, and live so,
Though prosperous in worldly understandings,
are but like beasts of rapine, that by odds
Of strength, usurp, and tyrannize o'er others
Brought under their subjection.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: A rare fellow!
I am strangely taken with him.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Can you think sir,
In your unquestioned wisdom, I beseech you,
The goods of this poor man sold at an outcry,
His wife turned out of doors, his children forced
To beg their bread: this gentleman's estate
By wrong extorted can advantage you?

sp.speaker: Hoyst.
sp.l: If it thrive with him hang me, as it will damn him
If he be not converted.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: You are too violent.
Or that the ruin of this once brave merchant
(For such he was esteemed though now decayed)
Will raise your reputation with good men.
But you may urge, pray you pardon me, my zeal
Makes me thus bold and vehement, in this
You satisfy your anger, and revenge
For being defeated. Suppose this, it will not
Repair your loss, and there was never yet
But shame, and scandal in a victory
When the rebels unto reasons passions fought it.
Then for revenge by great souls it was ever
Contemned, though offered; entertained by none
But cowards, base, and abject spirits, strangers
To moral honesty, and never yet
Acquainted with religion.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Our divines
Cannot speak more effectually.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Shall I be
Talked out of my money?

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: No, sir, but entreated
To do yourself a benefit, and preserve
What you possess entire.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: How my good brother?

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: By making these your beadsmen. When they eat,
their thanks next heaven, will be paid to your mercy
When your ships are at sea, their prayers will swell
The sails with prosperous winds, and guard 'em from
Tempests, and pirates: keep your warehouses
From fire, or quench 'em with their tears.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: No more.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Write you a good man in the people's hearts,
Follow you everywhere .

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: If this could be.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: It must or our devotions are but words,
I see a gentle promise in your eye,
Make it a blessed act, and poor, me rich
In being the instrument.

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.l: You shall prevail.
Give 'em longer day. But do you hear, no talk of't.
Should this arrive at twelve on the exchange.
I shall be laughed at for my foolish pity.
Which money men hate deadly. Take your own time
But see you break not. Carry 'em to the cellar,
Drink a health, and thank your orator.

sp.speaker: Penury.
sp.l: On our knees sir.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: Honest m. Luke!

sp.speaker: Hoyst.
sp.l: I bless the counter where
You learned this rhetoric.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: No more of that friends.

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.l: My honourable lord

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: I have seen and heard all,
Excuse my manners, and wish heartily
You were all of a piece. Your charity to your debtors
I do commend, but where you should express
Your piety to the height, I must boldly tell you
You show yourself an atheist.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Make me know
My error, and for what I am thus censured,
And I will purge myself, or else confess
A guilty cause.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: It is your harsh demeanour
To your poor brother.

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.l: Is that all?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: 'Tis more
Than can admit defence. You keep him as
A parasite to your table, subject to
The scorn of your proud wife: an underling
To his own nieces. And can I with mine honour
Mix my blood with his, that is not sensible
Of his brother's miseries?

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.l: Pray you take me with you,
And let me yield my reasons why I am
No opener handed to him. I was born
His elder brother, yet my father's fondness
To him the younger robbed me of my birthright:
He had a fair estate, which his loose riots
Soon brought to nothing. Wants grew heavy on him
And when laid up for debt, of all forsaken,
And in his own hopes lost, I did redeem him,

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: You could not do less.

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.l: Was I bound to it my lord?
What I possess, I may with justice call
The harvest of my industry. Would you have me,
Neglecting mine own family, to give up
My estate to his disposure?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: I would have you,
What's passed forgotten, to use him as a brother;
A brother of fair parts, of a clear soul,
Religious, good, and honest.

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.l: Outward gloss
Often deceives, may it not prove so in him,
And yet my long acquaintance with his nature
Renders me doubtful, but that shall not make
A breach between us: let us in to dinner,
And what trust, or employment you think sit
Shall be conferred upon him: if he prove
True gold in the touch, I'll be no mourner for it.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: If counterfeit, I'll never trust my judgement.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.l: The like was never seen.

sp.speaker: Luk.
sp.l: Why in this rage man?

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.l: Men may talk of country-christmases, and courtgluttony,
Their thirty pound buttered eggs, their pies of carps tongues,
Their pheasants drenched with ambergris, the carcases
Of three fat wethers bruised for gravy to
Make sauce for a single peacock, yet their feasts
Were fasts compared with the cities.

sp.speaker: Tradewell.
sp.l: What dear dainty
Was it thou murmurest at?

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.l: Did you not observe it?
There were three sucking pigs served up in a dish,
Took from the sow as soon as farrowed,
A fortnight fed with dates, and muskadine,
That stood my master in twenty marks a piece,
Besides the puddings in their bellies made
Of I know not what. I dare swear the cook that dressed it
Was the devil, disguised like a Dutchman.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: Yet all this
Will not make you fat, fellow. Holdfast.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.l: I am rather
Starved to look on't. But here's the mischief, though
The dishes were raised one upon another
As woodmongers do billets, for the first,
The second, and third course, and most of the shops
Of the best confectioners in London ransacked
To furnish out a banquet, yet my lady
Called me penurious rascal, and cried out,
There was nothing worth the eating.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: You must have patience,
this is not done often.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.l: 'Tis not fit it should,
Three such dinners more would break an alderman,
And make him give up his cloak. I am resolved
To have no hand in't. I'll make up my accounts
And since, my master longs to be undone:
The great fiend be his steward, I will pray,
And bless myself from him.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: The wretch shows in this
An honest care.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Out on him, with the fortune
Of a slave, he has the mind of one. However
She bears me hard, I like my lady's humour,
And my brother's suffrage to it. They are now
Busy on all hands; one side eager for
Large portions, the other arguing strictly
For jointures, and security; but this
Being above our scale, no way concerns us.
How dull you look? in the mean time how intend you
To spend the hours?

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: We well know how we would,
But dare not serve our wills.

sp.speaker: Tradewell.
sp.l: Being prentices,
We are bound to attendance.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Have you almost served out
The term of your indentures, yet make conscience
By starts to use your liberty? Hast thou traded
In the other world, exposed unto all dangers,
To make thy master rich, yet dar'st not take
Some portion of the profit for thy pleasure?
Or wilt thou being keeper of the cash,
Like an ass that carries dainties, feed on thistles?
Are you gentlemen born, yet have no gallant tincture
Of gentry in you? You are no mechanics,
Nor serve some needy shopkeeper, who surveys
His every-day-takings. You have in your keeping,
A mass of wealth, from which you may take boldly,
And no way be discovered, he's no rich man
that knows all he possesses, and leaves nothing
For his servants to make prey of. I blush for you,
Blush at your poverty of spirit, you
The brave sparks of the city?

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: M. Luke,
I wonder, you should urge this, having felt
What misery follows riot.

sp.speaker: Tradewell.
sp.l: And the penance
You endured for't in the counter.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: You are fools,
The case is not the same. I spent mine own money,
And my stock being small, no marvel 'twas soon wasted.
But you without the least doubt or suspicion,
If cautelous, may make bold with your masters.
As for example; when his ships come home,
And you take your receipts, as 'tis the fashion,
For fifty bales of silk you may write forty,
Or for so many pieces of cloth of bodkin,
Tissue, gold, silver, velvets, satins, taffeties,
A piece of each deducted from the gross
Will never be missed, a dash of a pen will do it.

sp.speaker: Trad.
sp.l: Ay, but our father's bonds that lie in pawn
For our honesties must pay for't.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: A mere bugbear
Invented to fright children. As I live
Were I the master of my brother's fortunes,
I should glory in such servants. Didst thou know
What ravishing lechery it is to enter
An ordinary, ca pa poe, trimmed like a gallant,
(For which in trunks concealed be ever furnished)
The reverence, respect, the crouches, cringes,
The musical chime of gold in your crammed pockets,
Commands from the attendants, and poor porters?

sp.speaker: Tradewell.
sp.l: O rare!

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Then sitting at the table with
The braveries of the kingdom, you shall hear
Occurrents from all corners of the world,
The plots, the counsels, the designs of princes,
and freely censure 'em; the city wits
Cried up, or decried, as their passions lead 'em;
Judgement having naught to do there.

sp.speaker: Tradewell.
sp.l: Admirable!

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: My lord no sooner shall rise out of his chair,
The gameing lord I mean, but you may boldly
By the privilege of a gamester fill his room,
For in play you are all fellows; have your knife
As soon in the pheasant; drink your health as freely,
And striking in a lucky hand or two,
Buy out your time.

sp.speaker: Tradewell.
sp.l: This may be: but suppose
We should be known.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Have money and good clothes
And you may pass invisible. Or if
You love a madam-punk, and your wide nostril
Be taken with the scent of cambric smocks
Wrought, and perfumed.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: There, there, m. Luke,
There lies my road of happiness.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Enjoy it,
And pleasures stolen being sweetest, apprehend
The raptures of being hurried in a coach
To Brainford, Stanes, or Barnet.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: 'Tis enchanting,
I have proved it.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Hast thou?

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: Yes in all these places,
I have had my several pagans billeted
For my own tooth, and after ten pound suppers
The curtains drawn, my fiddlers playing all night
The shaking of the sheets, which I have danced
Again, and again with my cockatrice. M. Luke,
You shall be of my counsel, and we two sworn brothers,
And therefore I'll be open. I am out now
Six hundred in the cash, yet if on a sudden
I should be called to account, I have a trick
How to evade it, and make up the sum.

sp.speaker: Tradewell.
sp.l: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: You can intrust your tutor.
How? how? good Tom.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: Why look you. We cash-keepers
Hold correspondence, supply one another
On all occasions. I can borrow for a week
Two hundred pounds of one, as much of a second,
A third lays down the rest, and when they want,
As my master's moneys come in, I do repay it,
Ka me, ka thee.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: An excellent knot! 'tis pity
It e'er should be unloosed; for me it shall not,
You are shown the way friend Tradewell, ou may make use on't,
Or freeze in the warehouse, and keep company
With the cator holdfast.

sp.speaker: Tradewell.
sp.l: No, I am converted.
A Barbican broker will furnish me with outside ,
And then a crash at the ordinary.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: I am for
The lady you saw this morning, who indeed is
My proper recreation.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Go to Tom,
What did you make me?

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: I'll do as much for you,
Employ me when you please:

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: If you are inquired for,
I will excuse you both.

sp.speaker: Tradewell.
sp.l: Kind m. Luke;

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: We'll break my master to make you;
You know.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: I cannot love money, go boys. When time serves
It shall appear, I have another end in't.

div.stage: Enter lord, sir John, Lacy, plenty, lady, Ann, Marry, Milliscent.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Ten thousand pounds a piece I'll make their portions,
And after my decease it shall be double,
provided you assure them for their jointures
800l. per annum, and entail
A thousand more upon the heirs male,
Begotten on their bodies.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Sir, you bind us
To very strict conditions.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: You my lord
May do as you please: but to me it seems strange,
We should conclude of portions, and of jointures,
Before our hearts are settled.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: You say right,
There are counsels of more moment, and importance
On the making up of marriages to be
Considered duly, than the portion, or the jointures
In which a mother's care must be exacted,
And I by special privilege may challenge
A casting voice.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Even so my lord,
In these affairs I govern.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Give you way to't?

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.l: I must my lord.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: 'Tis fit he should, and shall:
You may consult of something else, this province
Is wholly mine.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: By the city custom madam?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Yes my young sir, and both must look my daughters
Will hold it by my copy.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: Brave i'faith.

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.l: Give her leave to talk, we have the power to do;
And now touching the business we last talked of,
In private if you please.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: 'Tis well remembered,
You shall take your own way madam.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: What strange lecture
Will she read unto us?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Such as wisdom warrants
From the superior bodies. Is Stargaze ready
with his several schemes?

sp.speaker: Millis.
sp.l: Yes madam, and attends
Your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: Stargaze, lady: what is he?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Call him in. You shall first know him, then admire him
For a man of many parts, and those parts rare ones.
He's every thing indeed, parcel physician,
And as such prescribes my diet, and foretells
My dreams when I eat potatoes; parcel poet,
And sings encomiums to my virtues sweetly;
My antecedent, or my gentleman usher;
And as the stars move, with that due proportion
He walks before me; but an absolute master
In the calculation of nativities;
Guided by that never-erring science, called,
Judicial astrology.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: Stargaze! sure
I have a penny almanac about me
Inscribed to you, as to his patroness,
In his name published.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Keep it as a jewel.
Some states men that I will not name, are wholly
Governed by his predictions, for they serve
For any latitude in Christendom,
As well as our own climate.
sp.stage: Enter Milliscent, and Stargaze, with two schemes.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I believe so.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: Must we couple by the almanac?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Be silent,
And ere we do articulate, much more
Grow to a full conclusion, instruct us
Whether this day and hour, by the planets, promise
Happy success in, marriage.

sp.speaker: Stargaze.
sp.l: In omni
Parte, et toto.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: Good learned sir, in English.
And since it is resolved we must be coxcombs,
Make us so in our own language.

sp.speaker: Stargaze.
sp.l: You are pleasant:
Thus in our vulgar tongue then.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Pray you observe him.

sp.speaker: Stargaze.
sp.l: Venus in the west-angle, the house of marriage the
7th house, in trine of Mars, in conjunction of Luna, and Mars
Almuthen, or lord of the horoscope.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: Hoy day

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: The angel's language, I am ravished! forward.

sp.speaker: Stargaze.
sp.p: Mars as I said lord of the horoscope, or geniture, in mutual reception of each other, she in her exaltation, and he in his triplicity trine, and face, assure a fortunate combination to Hymen. excellent prosperous and happy.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Kneel, and give thanks.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: For what we understand not.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: And have as little faith in't.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Be credulous,
To me 'tis oracle.

sp.speaker: Stargaze.
sp.p: Now for the sovereignty of my future ladies, your daughters after they are married.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: Wearing the breeches you mean.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Touch that point home,
It is a principal one, and with London ladies
Of main consideration.

sp.speaker: Stargaze
sp.p: This is infallible: Saturn out of all dignities in his detriment and fall, combust: and Venus in the south-angle elevated above him, lady of both their nativities; in her essential, and accidental dignities; occidental from the sun, Oriental from the angle of the East, in cazini of the sun, in her joy, and free from the malevolent beams of infortunes; in a sign commanding, and Mars in a constellation obeying, she fortunate, and he dejected, the disposers of marriage in the radix of the native in feminine figures, argue foretell, and declare pre-eminence, rule, eminence ce and absolute sovereignty in women.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: Is't possible!

sp.speaker: Stargaze.
sp.l: 'Tis drawn, I assure you, from the aphorisms of the old Chaldeans;
Zoroaster the first and greatest magician,
Mercurius Trismegistius, the later Ptolemy, and the everlasting
Prognosticator, old erra pater.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Are you yet satisfied!

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: In what?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: That you
Are bound to obey your wives, it being so
Determined by the stars, against whose influence
There is no opposition.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: Since I must
Be married by the almanac, as I may be,
'Twere requisite the services and duties
Which, as you say, I must pay to my wife,
Were set down in the calendar.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: With the date
Of my apprenticeship.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Make your demands;
I'll sit as moderatrix, if they press you
With over hard conditions.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: Mine hath the van,
I stand your charge, sweet.

sp.speaker: Stargaze.
sp.l: Silence.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: I require first
(And that since 'tis in fashion with kind husbands,
In civil manners you must grant) my will
In all things whatsoever, and that will
To be obeyed, not argued.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: And good reason.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: A gentle imprimis.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: This in gross contains all;
But your special items, lady.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: When I am one
(And you are honoured to be styled my husband)
To urge my having my page, my gentleman-usher;
My woman sworn to my secrets; my caroche
Drawn by six Flanders mares; my coachman, grooms,
Postilion, and footmen.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: Is there ought else
To be demanded?

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Yes sir, mine own doctor; French, and Italian cooks;
Musicians, songsters,
And a chaplain that must preach to please my fancy;
a friend at court to place me at a mask;
The private box took up at a new play
For me, and my retinue; a fresh habit,
(Of a fashion never seen before) to draw
The gallants eyes that sit on the stage upon me;
Some decayed lady for my parasite,
To flatter me, and rail at other madams;
And there ends my ambition.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: Your desires
Are modest, I confess.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: These toys subscribed to,
And you continuing an obedient husband
Upon all fit occasions, you shall find me
A most indulgent wife.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: You have said, give place
And hear your younger sister.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: If she speak
Her language, may the great friend booted and spurred,
With a scythe at his girdle, as the Scotchman says,
Ride headlong down her throat.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: Curse not the judge
Before you hear the sentence.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: In some part
My sister hath spoke well for the city pleasures,
But I am for the countries, and must say
Under correction in her demands
She was too modest.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: How like you this exordium?

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: Too modest, with a mischief I

sp.speaker: Marry.
sp.l: Yes, too modest:
I know my value, and prize it to the worth;
My youth, my beauty.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: How your glass deceives you?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: The greatness of the portion I bring with me,
And the sea of happiness that from me flows to you.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: She bears up close.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: And can you in your wisdom,
Or rustical simplicity imagine,
you have met some innocent country girl, that never
Looked further than her father's farm, nor knew more
Than the price of corn in the market; or at what rate
Beef went a stone? that would survey your dairy,
And bring in mutton out of cheese, and butter?
That could give directions at what time of the moon
To cut her cocks, for (Apons against Christmas,
Or when to raise up goslings?

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: These are arts
Would not misbecome you, though you should put in
Obedience and duty.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Yes, and patience,
To sit like a fool at home, and eye your thrashers;
Then make provision for your slavering round,
When you come drunk from an alehouse after hunting,
With your clowns and comrades as if all were yours,
You the lord Paramount, and I the drudge;
The case sir, must be otherwise.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: How, I beseech you?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Marry thus. I will not like my sister challenge
What's useful, or superfluous from my husband,
That's base all o'er. mine shall receive from me,
What I think fit. I'll have the state conveyed
Into my hands; and be put to his pension,
Which the wise viragoes of our climate practise,
I will receive your rends.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: You shall be hanged first.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Make sale, or purchase. Nay I'll have my neighbours
Instructed, when a passenger shall ask,
Whose house is this? though you stand by to answer,
The lady plenties. Or who owes this manner?
The lady plenty. Whose sheep are these? whose oxen?
The lady plenties.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: A plentiful pox upon you

sp.speaker: Marry.
sp.l: And when I have children, if it be enquired
By a stranger whose they are, they shall still echo
My lady plenties? the husband never thought on.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: In their begetting I think so.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Since you'll marry
In the city for our wealth, in justice, we
Must have the country's sovereignty.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: And we nothing.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: A nag of forty shillings, a couple of spaniels,
With a sparhawk is sufficient, and these too,
As you shall behave yourself, during my pleasure,
I will not greatly stand on. I have said sir,
Now if you like me, so.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: At my entreaty,
The articles shall be easier.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: Shall they i'faith?
Like bitch, like whelps:

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: Use fair words.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: I cannot;
I have read of a house of pride, and now I have found one:
A whirl wind overturn it.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: On these terms,
Will your minxship be a lady?

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: A lady in a morris,
I'll wed a pedlar's punk first.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: Tinker's trull,
A beggar without a smock.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: Let monsieur almanac,
Since he is so cunning with his Jacob's staff,
Find you out a husband in a bowling alley

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: The general pimp to a brothel.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: Though that now,
All the loose desires of man were raked up in me,
And no means but thy maidenhead left to quench 'em,
I would turn cinders, or the next sowgelder,
On my life should libb me, rather than embrace thee.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Wooing do you call this?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: A bear-baiting rather.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: Were you worried, you deserve it, and I hope
I shall live to see it.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: I'll not rail, nor curse you,
Only this; you are pretty peats, and your great portions
adds much unto your handsomeness, but as
You would command your husbands you are beggars,
Deformed, and ugly.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Hear me.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: Not a word more.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: I ever thought 'twould come to this.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: We may
Lead apes in hell for husbands, if you bind us
To articulate thus with our suitors.

sp.speaker: Stargaze.
sp.l: Now the cloud breaks,
And the storm will fall on me.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: You rascal, juggler.
sp.stage: She breaks his head, and beats him.

sp.speaker: Stargaze.
sp.l: Dear madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Hold you intelligence with the stars,
And thus deceive me?

sp.speaker: Stargaze.
sp.l: My art cannot err,
If it does I'll burn my astrolabe. In mine own star
I did fore see this broken head, and beating;
And now your ladyship sees, as I do feel it,
It could not be avoided.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Did you?

sp.speaker: Stargaze.
sp.l: Madam,
Have patience but a week, and if you find not
All my predictions true touching your daughters,
And a change of fortune to yourself, a rare one,
Turn me out of doors. These are not the men, the planets
Appointed for their husbands, there will come
Gallants of another metal.

sp.speaker: Milliscent.
sp.l: Once more trust him.

sp.speaker: Ann. and Mary.
sp.l: Do, lady mother.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I am vexed, look to it;
Turn o'er your books, if once again you fool me,
You shall graze elsewhere: come girls.

sp.speaker: Stargaze.
sp.l: I am glad I scaped thus.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: The plot shows very likely.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: I repose
My principal trust in your lordship; 'twill prepare
The physic I intend to minister
To my wife, and daughters.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: I will do my parts
To set it off to the life.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: It may produce
A scene of no vulgar mirth. Here come the suitors;
When we understand how they relish my wife's humours,
The rest is feasible.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Their looks are cloudy.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: How fits the wind? Are you ready to launch forth.
Into this sea of marriage.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: Call it rather
A whirlpool of afflictions.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: If you please
To enjoin me to it, I will undertake
To find the north-passage to the Indies sooner,
Than plough with your proud heifer.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: I will make
A voyage to hell first.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: How, sir?

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: And court Proserpine
In the fight of Pluto, his three headed porter
Cerberus standing by, and all the furies,
With their whips to scourge me for't, then say, I Jeffrey
Take your Mary for my wife.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Why what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: The matter is, the mother, with your pardon,
I cannot but speak so much, is a most insufferable,
Proud, insolent lady.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: And the daughter's worse.
The dam in years had th'advantage to be wicked.
But they were so in her belly.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: I must tell you,
With reverence to your wealth, I do begin
To think you of the same leaven.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: Take my counsel;
'Tis safer for your credit to profess
Yourself a cuckold, and upon record,
Then say they are your daughters.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: You go too far sir.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: They have so articled with us.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: And will not take us
For their husbands, but their slaves, and so aforehand
They do profess they'll use us.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Leave this heat:
Though they are mine I must tell you, the perverseness
Of their manners (Which they did not take from me,
But from their mother) qualified, they deserve
Your equals.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: True, but what's bred in the bone
Admits no hope of cure:

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: Though saints, and angels
Were their physicians.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: You conclude too fast.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: God bye you, I'll travail three years, but I'll bury
This shame that lives upon me.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: With your licence,
I'll keep him company.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Who shall furnish you,
For your expenses?

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: He shall not need your help,
My purse is his, we were rivals, but now friends,
And will live and die so.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: Ere we go I'll pay
My duty as a son.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: And till then leave you.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: They are strangely moved.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: What's wealth, accompanied
With disobedience in a wife and children?
My heart will break

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Be comforted, and hope better;
We'll ride abroad, the fresh air and discourse,
May yield us new inventions.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: You are noble,
And shall in all things, as you please command me.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.l: Dead doings, daughter.

sp.speaker: Shave'm
sp.l: Doings! sufferings mother:
Men have forgotten what doing is;
And such as have to pay for what they do,
Are impotent, or eunuchs.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.l: You have a friend yet,
And a striker too, I take it.

sp.speaker: Shaveem.
sp.l: Goldwire is so,
And comes to me by stealth, and as he can steal, maintains me
In clothes, I grant; but alas dame, what's one friend?
I would have a hundred for every hour, and use
And change of humour I am in a fresh one.
'Tis a flock of sheep that makes a lean wolf fat,
And not a single lambkin. I am starved,
Starved in my pleasures. I know not what a coach is,
To hurry me to the burse, or old exchange,
The neathouse for muskmelons, and the gardens
Where we traffic for asparagus, are to me
In the other world.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.l: There are other places lady.
Where you might find customers.

sp.speaker: Shaveem.
sp.l: You would have me fout it
To the dancing of the ropes, sit a whole afternoon there
In expectation of nuts and pippins;
Gape round about me, and yet not find a chapman
That in courtesy will bid a chop of mutton,
Or a pint of drum-wine for me.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.l: You are so impatient.
But I can tell you news will comfort you,
And the whole sister hood.

sp.speaker: Shavem.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.l: I am told
Two ambassadors are come over. A French Monsieur,
And a Venetian, one of the clarissimi,
A hot reined marmosue. Their followers,
For their country's honour after a long vacation,
Will make a full term with us.

sp.speaker: Shavem.
sp.l: They indeed are
Our certain and best customers: who knocks there? Knock within.

sp.speaker: Within Ramble.
sp.l: Open the door.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.l: What are you?

sp.speaker: Within Ramble.
sp.l: Your constant visitants.

sp.speaker: Shaven.
sp.l: Let 'em not in.
I know 'em swaggering, suburban roarers,
Sixpenny truckers

sp.speaker: Within Ramble.
sp.l: Down go all your windows,
And your neighbours too shall suffer.

sp.speaker: Within scuffle.
sp.l: Force the doors.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.l: They are outlaws, mistress Shavem, and there is
No remedy against 'em, what should you fear?
They are but men, lying at your close ward,
You have foiled their betters.

sp.speaker: Shavem.
sp.l: Out you bawd. You care not
Upon what desperate service you employ me,
Nor with whom, so you have your fee.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.l: Sweet ladybird
Sing a milder key.

sp.speaker: Scuffle.
sp.l: Are you grown proud?

sp.speaker: Ramble.
sp.l: I knew you a waistcoatier in the garden allies,
And would come to a sailor's whistle.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.l: Good sir Ramble,
Use her not roughly. She is very tender.

sp.speaker: Ramble.
sp.l: Rank and rotten, is she not?
sp.stage: She draws her knife, Ramble his sword.

sp.speaker: Shavem.
sp.l: Your spittle rogueships
Shall not make me so.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.l: As you are a man, squire Scuffle,
Step in between 'em. A weapon of that length
Was never drawn in my house.

sp.speaker: Shavem.
sp.l: Let him come on,
I'll scour it in your gut, you dog.

sp.speaker: Ramble.
sp.l: You brach,
Are you turned mankind. You forgotten I gave you,
When we last joined issue, twenty pound.

sp.speaker: Shavem.
sp.l: O'er night,
And kick it out of me in the morning. I was then
A novice, but I know to make my game now.
Fetch the constable.
sp.stage: Enter Goldwire like a justice of peace, Dingem like a constable, the musicians like watch men.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.l: Ah me. Here's one unsent for,
And a justice of peace too.

sp.speaker: Shavem.
sp.l: I'll hang you both you rascals,
I can but ride. You for the purse you cut
In Powl's at a sermon. I have smoked you. And you for the bacon
You took on the high way from the poor market woman
As she road from Rumford.

sp.speaker: Ramble.
sp.l: Mistress Shavem.

sp.speaker: Scuffle.
sp.l: Mistress secret,
On our knees we beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Scuffle.
sp.l: Set a ransom on us.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.l: We cannot stand trifling. If you mean to save them,
Shut them out at the backdoor.

sp.speaker: Shavem.
sp.l: First for punishment
they shall leave their cloaks behind 'em, and in sign
I am their sovereign, and they my vassals,
For homage kiss my shoe-sole rogues, and vanish.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: My brave virago. The coasts clear. Strike up.

sp.speaker: Shavem.
sp.l: My Goldwire made a justice.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.l: And your scout
Turned constable, and the musicians watchmen.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: We come not to fright you, but to make you merry.
A light lavolta.

sp.speaker: Shavem.
sp.l: I am tired. No more.
This was your device.

sp.speaker: Dingem.
sp.l: Wholly his own. He is
No pig sconce mistress.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.l: He has an excellent head-piece

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: Fie no, not I: your jeering gallants say
We citizens have no wit.

sp.speaker: Dingem.
sp.l: He dies that says so.
This was a masterpiece.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: A trifling stratagem,
Not worth the talking of.

sp.speaker: Shavem.
sp.l: I must kiss thee for it
Again, and again.

sp.speaker: Dingem.
sp.l: Make much of her. Did you know
What suitors she had since she saw you.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: I'the way of marriage.

sp.speaker: Dingem.
sp.l: Yes sir, for marriage, and the other thing too.
The commodity is the same. An Irish lord offered her.
Five pound a week.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.l: And a cashiered captain, half
Of his entertainment.

sp.speaker: Dingem.
sp.l: And a new made courtier.
The next suit he could beg.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: And did my sweet one
Refuse all this for me?

sp.speaker: Shavem.
sp.l: Weep not for joy,
'Tis true. Let others talk of lords, and commanders,
And country heirs for their servants; but give me
My gallant prentice. He parts with his money
so civilly, and demurely; keeps no account
Of his expenses, and comes ever furnished.
I know thou hast brought money to make up
My gown and petticoat, with th'appurtenances.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: I have it here duck, thou shalt want for nothing.

sp.speaker: Shavem.
sp.l: Let the chamber be perfumed, and get you sirrah
His cap, and pantables ready.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: There's for thee,
And thee. That for a banquet.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.l: And a caudle
Again you rise.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: There.

sp.speaker: Shavem.
sp.l: Usher us up in state.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: You will be constant.

sp.speaker: Shavem.
sp.l: Thou art the whole world to me.

sp.speaker: Within Anne.
sp.l: Where is this uncle?

sp.speaker: Within lady.
sp.l: Call this beadsman, brother: he hath forgotten attendance.

sp.speaker: Within Marry.
sp.l: Seek him out: idleness spoils him.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: I deserve much more than their scorn can load me with, and 'tis but justice,
That I should live the family's drudge, designed
To all the sordid offices their pride
Imposes on me; since if now I sat
A judge in mine own cause, I should conclude
I am not worth their pity: such as want
Discourse, and judgement, and through weakness fall,
May merit man's compassion; but I
That knew profuseness of expense the parent
Of wretched poverty, her fatal daughter,
To riot out mine own, to live upon
the alms of others! steering on a rock
I might have shunned: oh heaven! 'tis not fit
I should look upward, much less hope for mercy.
sp.stage: Enter lady, Anne, Marry, Stargaze, and Milliscent.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: What are you devising, sir?

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: My uncle is much given to his devotion.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: And takes time to mumble
A pater noster to himself.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Know you where
Your brother is? It better would become you
(Your means of life depending wholly on him)
To give your attendance.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: In my will I do:
But since he road forth yesterday with lord Lacy,
I have not seen him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: And why went not you
By his stirrup? how do you look? were his eyes closed,
You'd be glad of such employment.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: 'Twas his pleasure
I should wait your command, and those I am ever
Most ready to receive.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I know you can speak well,
But say and do.
sp.stage: Enter lord Lacy with a Will.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Here comes my lord.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Further off:
You are no companion for him, and his business
Aims not at you, as I take it.

sp.speaker: Luke
sp.l: Can I live in this base condition?Aside

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I hoped, my lord,
You had brought Mr. frugal with you, for I must ask
An account of him from you.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: I can give it, lady;
But with the best discretion of a woman,
And a strong fortified patience, I desire you
To give it hearing

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: My heart beats.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: My lord, you much amaze me.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: I shall astonish you. The noble merchant,
Who living was for his integrity
And upright dealing (A rare miracle.
In a rich citizen) London's best honour;
Is — I am loath to speak it.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Wondrous strange!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I do suppose the worst, not dead I hope?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Your supposition's true, your hopes are false:
He's dead.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Ay me.

sp.speaker: Anne
sp.l: My father.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: My kind father.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Now they insult not.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Pray hear me out.
He's dead. Dead to the world, and you. And now
Lives only to himself.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: What riddle's this?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Act not the torturer in my afflictions;
But make me understand the sum of all
That I must undergo.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: In few words take it;
He is retired into a monastery,
Where he resolves to end his days.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: More strange.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: I saw him take post for Dover, and the wind
Sitting so fair, by this he's safe at Calice,
And ere long will be at Louvain.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Could I guess
What were the motives that induced him to it,
'Twere some allay to my sorrows.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: I'll instruct you,
And chide you into that knowledge: 'twas your pride
Above your rank, and stubborn disobedience
Of these your daughters, in their milk sucked from you:
At home the harshness of his entertainment,
You wilfully forgetting that your all
Was borrowed from him; and to hear abroad
The imputations dispersed upon you,
and justly too, I fear, that drew him to
This strict retirement: and thus much said for him;
I am myself to accuse you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I confess
A guilty cause to him, but in a thought,
My lord, I ne'er wronged you.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: In fact you have;
The insolent disgrace you put upon
My only son, and Mr. plenty; men, that loved
Your daughters in a noble way, to wash off
The scandal, put a resolution in 'em
For three years travel.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I am much grieved for it.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: One thing I had forgotten; your rigor to
His decaied brother, in which your flatteries,
Or sorceries, made him a coagent with you,
Wrought not the least impression.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Humph! this sounds well.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: 'Tis now past help: after these storms, my lord,
A little calm, if you please.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: If what I have told you
Showed like a storm, what now I must deliver
Will prove a raging tempest. His whole estate
In lands and leases, debts and present moneys,
With all the movables he stood possessed of,
With the best advice which he could get for gold
From his learned counsel, by this formal will
Is passed o'er to his brother. With it take
The key of his counting house. Not a groat left you,
Which you can call your own.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Undone for ever.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Marry. What will become of us?

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Humph!

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: The scenes changed,
And he that was your slave, by fate appointed
Your governor, you kneel to me in vain,
I cannot help you, I discharge the trust
Imposed upon me. This humility
from him may gain remission, and perhaps
Forgetfulness of your barbarous usage to him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Am I come to this.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Enjoy your own, good sir,
But use it with due reverence. I once heard you
Speak most divinely in the opposition
Of a revengeful humour, to these show it;
And such who then depended on the mercy
Of your brother wholly now at your devotion,
And make good the opinion I held of you;
Of which I am most confident.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Pray you rise,
And rise with this assurance, I am still,
As I was of late, your creature; and if raised
In any thing, 'tis in my power to serve you,
My will is still the same. O my lord!
This heap of wealth which you possess me of.
Which to a worldly man had been a blessing,
And to the messenger might with justice challenge
A kind of adoration, is to me
A curse, I cannot thank you for; and much less
Rejoice in that tranquillity of mind,
My brother's vows must purchase. I have made
A dear exchange with him. He now enjoys
My peace, and poverty, the trouble of
His wealth conferred on me, and that a burden
Too heavy for my weak shoulders.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Honest soul,
With what feeling he receives it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: You shall have
My best assistance, if you please to use it
To help you to support it.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: By no means,
The weight shall rather sink me, than you part
With one short minute from those lawful pleasures
Which you were born to in your care to aid me,
You shall have all abundance. In my nature
I was ever liberal, my lord you know it.
Kind, affable. And now methinks I see
Before my face the jubilee of joy,
When it is assured, my brother lives in me,
His debtors in full cups crowned to my health,
With paeans to my praise will celebrate.
For they well know 'tis far from me to take
The forfeiture of a bond. Nay I shall blush,
The interest never paid after three years,
When I demand my principal. And his servants
Who from a slavish fear paid her obedience
By him exacted; now when they are mine
Will grow familiar friends, and as such use me,
Being certain of the mildness of my temper,
Which my change of fortune, frequent in most men
Hath not the power to alter.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Yet take heed sir
You ruin it not with too much lenity,
What his fit severity raised.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: And we fall from
That height we have maintained.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: I'll build it higher,
To admiration higher. With disdain
I look upon these habits, no way suiting
The wife, and daughters of a knighted citizen
Blessed with abundance.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: There sir, I join with you;
A fit decorum must be kept, the court
Distinguished from the city.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: With your favour
I know what you would say, but give me leave
In this to be your advocate. You are wide,
Wide the whole region in what I purpose.
Since all the titles, honours, long descents
Borrow their gloss from wealth, the rich with reason
May challenge their prerogatives. And it shall be
My glory, nay a triumph to revive
In the pomp that these shall shine, the memory
Of the Roman matrons, who kept captive Queens
to be their handmaids. And when you appear
Like Juno in full majesty, and my nieces
Like Iris, Hebe, or what deities else
Old poet's fancy; your crammed wardrobes richer
Than various natures, and draw down the envy
Of our western world upon you, only hold me
Your vigilant Hermes with aerial wings,
My caduceus my strong zeal to serve you,
Pressed to fetch in all rarities may delight you,
And am made immortal.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: A strange frenzy.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Off with these rags, and then to bed. There dream
Of future greatness, which when you awake
I'll make a certain truth: but I must be
A doer, not a promiser. The performance
Requiring host, I kiss your hands, and leave you.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Are we all turned statues: have his strange words charmed us?
What muse you on lady?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Do not trouble me.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Sleep you too, young ones?

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Swift winged time till now
Was never tedious to me. Would 'twere night.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Nay morning rather.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Can you ground your faith
On such impossibilities? have you so soon
Forgotten your good husband?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: He was a vanity
I must no more remember.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Excellent!
You your kind father?

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Such an uncle never
Was read of in story!

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Not one word in answer
Of my demands?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: You are but a lord, and know
My thoughts soar higher.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Admirable! I will leave you
To your castles in the air, when I relate this
it will exceed belief, but he must know it.

sp.speaker: Stargaze.
sp.l: Now I may boldly speak: may it please you madam,
To look upon your vassal; I foresaw this,
The stars assured it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I begin to feel
Myself another woman.

sp.speaker: Stargaze.
sp.l: Now you shall find
All my predictions true, and nobler matches
Prepared for my young ladies.

sp.speaker: Milliscent.
sp.l: Princely husbands.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: I'll go no less.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Not a word more,
Provide my night-rail.

sp.speaker: Millisc.
sp.l: What shall we be tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: 'Twas no fantastic object, but a truth
A real truth. Nor dream I did not slumber,
And could wake ever with a brooding eye
To gaze upon't! It did endure the touch,
I saw, and felt it. Yet what I beheld
And handled oft, did so transcend belief
(My wonder, and astonishment passed o'er)
I faintly could give credit to my senses.
Thou dumb magician that without a charm
Didst make my entrance easy, to possess
What wise men wish, and toil for. Hermes moly;
Sybilla's golden bough; the great elixir,
Imagined only by the alchemist
Compared with thee are shadows, thou the substance.
And guardian of felicity. No marvel,
My brother made thy place of rest his bosom,
Thou being the keeper of his heart, a mistress
To be hugged ever. In by corners of
this sacred room, silver in bags heaped up
Like billets sawed, and ready for the fire,
Unworthy to hold fellowship with bright gold
That flowed about the room, concealed itself.
There needs no artificial light, the splendour
Makes a perpetual day there, night and darkness
By that still burning lamp for ever banished.
But when guided by that, my eyes had made
Discovery of the caskets, and they opened,
Each sparkling diamond from itself shot forth
A pyramid of flames, and in the roof
Fix it a glorious star, and made the place
Heaven's abstract, or epitome. Rubies, saphires, and ropes of orient pearl; these seen I could not
But look on with contempt, and yet I found
What weak credulity could have no faith in
A treasure far exceeding these, here lay
A manor bound fast in a skin of parchment,
The wax continuing hard, the acres melting.
Here a sure deed of gift for a market town,
If not redeemed this day, which is not in
The unthrists power. There being scarce one shire
In Wales or England's where my moneys are not
Lent out at usury, the certain hook
To draw in more. I am sublimed! gross earth
Supports me not. I walk on air! who's there
Theius, raise the street, thieves!
sp.stage: Enter lord, sir John, Lacy, and plenty, as Indians.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: What strange passion's this?
Have you your eyes? do you know me?

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: You, my lord!
I do: but this retinue, in these shapes too,
May well excuse my fears. When 'tis your pleasure
That I should wait upon you, give me leave
To do it at your own house, for I must tell you,
Things as they now are with me, well considered,
I do not like such visitants.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Yesterday
when you had nothing, praise your poverty for't,
You could have sung secure before a thief;
But now you are grown rich, doubts and suspicions,
And needless fears possess you. Thank a good brother,
But let not this exalt you.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: A good brother:
Good in his conscience, I confess, and wise,
In giving o'er the world. But his estate
Which your lordship may conceive great, no way answers
The general opinion. Alas,
With a great charge, I am left a poor man by him.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: A poor man, say you?

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Poor, compared with what
'Tis thought I do possess. Some little land,
Fair household furniture; a few good debts,
But empty bags I find: yet I will be
A faithful steward to his wife and daughters,
And to the utmost of my power obey
His will in all things

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: I'll not argue with you
Of his estate, but bind you to performance
Of his last request, which is for testimony
Of his religious charity, that you would
Receive these Indians, lately sent him from
Virginia, into your house; and labour
At any rate with the best of your endeavours,
Assisted by the aids of our divines,
To make 'em Christians.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Call you this, my lord,
Religious charity? to send infidel,
Like hungry locusts, to devour the bread
Should feed his family. I neither can,
Nor will consent to't.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Do not slight it, 'tis
With him a business of such consequence,
That should he only hear 'tis not embraced,
And cheerfully, in this his conscience aiming
At the saving of three souls, 'twill draw him o'er
to see it himself accomplished.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Heaven forbid
I should divert him from his holy purpose
To worldly cares again. I rather will
Sustain the burden, and with the converted
Feast the converters, who I know will prove
The greater feeders.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: O, ha, enewah Christ bully leika.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: Enaula.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: Harrico botikia bonnery.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Ha! in this heathen language,
How is it possible our doctors should
Hold conference with 'em? or I use the means
For their conversion?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: That shall be no hindrance
To your good purposes. They have lived long
In the English colony, and speak our language
As their own dialect; the business does concern you:
Mine own designs command me hence. Continue,
As in your poverty you were, a pious
And honest man

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: That is, interpreted,
A slave, and beggar.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: You conceive it right,
There being no religion, nor virtue
But in abundance, and no vice but want.
All deities serve Plutus.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Oracle.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Temples raised to ourselves in the increase
Of wealth, and reputation, speak a wiseman;
But sacrifice to an imagined power,
Of which we have no sense, but in belief,
A superstitious fool.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: True worldly wisdom.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: All knowledge else is folly.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Now we are yours,
Be confident your better angel is
Entered your house.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: There being nothing in
The compass of your wishes, but shall end
In their fruition to the full.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: As yet,
You do not know us, but when you understand
The wonders we can do, and what the ends were
That brought us hither, you will entertain us
With more respect.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: There's something whispers to me,
These are no common men; my house is yours,
Enjoy it freely: only grant me this,
Not to be seen abroad till I have heard
More of your sacred principles, pray enter.
You are learned Europians, and we worse
Than ignorant Americans.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: You shall find it.

sp.speaker: Dingem.
sp.l: Not speak with him? with fear survey me better;
Thou figure of famine.

sp.speaker: Gettal.
sp.l: Coming, as we do,
From his quondam patrons, his dear ingles now,
The brave spark Tradewell.

sp.speaker: Dingem.
sp.l: And the man of men
In the service of a woman, gallant Goldwire.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.l: I know 'em for his prentices without
These flourishes. Here are rude fellows sir.

sp.speaker: Dingem.
sp.l: Not yours, you rascal?

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.l: No, don pimp: you may seek 'em
In Bridewell, or the hole, here are none of your comrogues.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: One of 'em looks as he would cut my throat:
Your business, friends?

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.l: I'll fetch a constable,
Let him answer him in the stocks.

sp.speaker: Dingem.
sp.l: Stir and thou dar'st.
Fright me with Bridewell and the stocks? they are flea-bitings
I am familiar with

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Pray you put up.
And sirrah hold your peace.

sp.speaker: Dingem.
sp.l: Thy words a law,
And I obey. Live scrape-shoo, and be thankful.
Thou man of muck, and money, for as such
Know salute thee. The suburban gamesters
Have heard thy fortunes, and I am in person sent to congratulate.

sp.speaker: Gettal.
sp.l: The news hath reached
The ordinaries, and all the gamesters are
Ambitious to shake the golden golls
Of worshipful Mr. Luke. I come from Tradewell
Your fine facetious factor

sp.speaker: Dingem.
sp.l: I from Goldwire.
He and his Helen have prepared a banquet
With the appurtenances to entertain thee,
For I must whisper in thine ear, thou art
To be her Paris, but bring money with thee
To quit old scores.

sp.speaker: Gettall.
sp.l: Blind chance hath frowned upon
Brave Tradewell. He's blown up, but not without
Hope of recovery, so you supply him
With a good round sum. In my house I can assure you
There's half a million stirring.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: What hath he lost?

sp.speaker: Gettal.
sp.l: Three hundred.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: A trifle.

sp.speaker: Gettall.
sp.l: Make it up a thousand,
And I will fit him with such tools as shall
Bring in a myriad.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: They know me well,
Nor need you use such circumstances for 'em.
What's mine is theirs. They are my friends, not servants;
but in their care to enrich me, and these courses
The speeding means. Your name, I pray you?

sp.speaker: Gett.
sp.l: Gettall;
I have been many years an ordinary-keeper,
My box my poor revenue.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Your name suits well
With your profession. Bid him bear up, he shall not
Sit 'Ong on penniless-bench.

sp.speaker: Gettall.
sp.l: There spoke an angel.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: You know mistress Shave'm?

sp.speaker: Gettall.
sp.l: The pontifical punk.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: The same. Let him meet me there some two hours hence,
And tell Tom Goldwire I will then be with him,
Furnished beyond his hopes, and let your mistress
Appear in her best trim.

sp.speaker: Dinge'm.
sp.l: She will make thee young,
Old Aeson. She is ever furnished with
Medea's drugs, restoratives. I fly
To keep 'em sober till thy worship come,
They will be drunk with joy else.

sp.speaker: Gettall.
sp.l: I'll run with you.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.l: You will not do as you say, I hope.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Inquire not,
I shall do what becomes me — to the door. Knocking.
New visitants: what are they?

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.l: A whole batch, sir,
Almost of the same leaven: your needy debtors,
Penury, fortune, Hoyst.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: They come to gratulate
The fortune fallen upon me.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.l: Rather, sir,
Like the others, to prey on you.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: I am simple,
They know my good nature. But let 'em in however.

sp.speaker: Holdf.
sp.l: All will come to ruin, I see beggary
Already knocking at the door. You may enter —
But use a conscience, and do not work upon
a tender-hearted gentleman too much,
'Twill show like charity in you.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Welcome friends:
I know your hearts, and wishes; you are glad
You have changed your creditor.

sp.speaker: Penury.
sp.l: I weep for joy
To look upon his worship's face.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: His worships?
I see lord major written on his forehead;
