The cap of maintenance, and city sword
Born up in state before him.

sp.speaker: Hoyst.
sp.l: Hospitals,
And a third burse erected by his honour.

sp.speaker: Penury.
sp.l: The city poet on the pageant-day
Preferring him before Gresham.

sp.speaker: Hoyst.
sp.l: All the conduits
Spouting canary sack.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: Not a prisoner left,
Under ten pounds.

sp.speaker: Penury.
sp.l: We his poor beadsmen feasting
Our neighbours on his bounty.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: May I make good
Your prophecies, gentle friends, as I'll endeavour
To the utmost of my power.

sp.speaker: Holdf.
sp.l: Yes, for one year,
And break the next.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: You are ever prating, sirrah:
Your present business, friends?

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: Were your brother present,
Mine had been of some consequence; but now
The power lies in your worship's hand, 'tis little,
And will I know, as soon as asked, be granted.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: 'I is very probable.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: The kind forbearance
Of my great debt, by your means, heaven praised for't,
Hath raised my sunk estate. I have two ships,
Which I long since gave lost, above my hopes
returned from Barbary, and richly freighted.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Where are they?

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: Near Gravesend.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: I am truly glad of't.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: I find your worship's charity, and dare swear so.
Now may I have your licence, as I know
With willingness I shall, to make the best
Of the commodities, though you have execution,
And after judgement against all that's mine,
As my poor body, I shall be enabled
To make payment of my debts to all the world,
And leave myself a competence.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: You much wrong me,
If you only doubt it. Yours Mr. Hoyst.

sp.speaker: Hoyst
sp.l: 'Tis the surrendering back the mortgage of
My lands, and on good terms, but three days' patience;
By an uncle's death I have means lest to redeem it,
And cancel all the forfeited bonds I sealed too
In my riots to the merchant, for I am
Resolved to leave off play, and turn good husband.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: A good intent, and to be cherished in you.
Yours penury.

sp.speaker: Penury.
sp.l: My state stands as it did, sir:
What I owed I owe, but can pay nothing to you.
Yet if you please to trust me with ten pounds more,
I can buy a commodity of a sailor
Will make me a freeman. There sir is his name;
And the parcels I am to deal for. Gives him a paper.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: You are all so reasonable
In your demands, that I must freely grant 'em.
Some three hours hence meet me on the exchange,
You shall be amply satisfied.

sp.speaker: Penury.
sp.l: Heaven preserve you.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: Happy were London if within her walls
She had many such rich men.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: No more, now leave me;
I am full of various thoughts. Be careful holdfast
I have much to do.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.l: And I something to say
Would you give me hearing.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: At my better leisure
Till my return, look well unto the Indians.
In the mean time do you as this directs you.

sp.stage: Enter Goldwire, Tradewell. Shavem, secret, Gettal, and Dingem.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: All that is mine is theirs. Those were his words

sp.speaker: Dingem.
sp.l: I am authentical.

sp.speaker: Tradewell.
sp.l: And that I should not
Sit long on penniless bench.

sp.speaker: Gettall.
sp.l: But suddenly start up
A gamester at the height, and cry at all.

sp.speaker: Shavem.
sp.l: And did he seem to have an inclination
To toy with me?

sp.speaker: Dingem.
sp.l: He wished you would put on
Your best habiliments, for he resolved
To make a jovial day on't.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: Hug him close wench,
And thou may't eat gold, and amber. I well know him
For a most insatiate drabber. He hath given,
Before he spent his own estate, which was
Nothing to the huge mass he's now possessed of,
A hundred pound a leap.

sp.speaker: Shavem.
sp.l: Hell take my doctor,
He should have brought me some fresh oil of talk,
These ceruses are common.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.l: Troth sweet lady,
The colours are well laid on.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: And thick enough,
find that on my lips.

sp.speaker: Shavem.
sp.l: Do you so, Jack sauce.
I'll keep 'em further of.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: But be assured first
Of a new maintainer ere you cashier the old one.
But bind him fast by thy forceries, and thou shalt
Be my revenue; the whole college study,
The reparation of thy ruined face;
Thou shalt have thy proper and bald-headed coachman:
Thy tailor, and embroiderer shall kneel
To thee their idol. Cheapside and the exchange shall court thy custom, and thou shalt forget
There ever was a saint Martin's. Thy procurer
Shall be sheathed in velvet, and a reverend vail
Pass her for a grave marton. Have an eye to the door,
And let loud music when this monarch enters
Proclaim his entertainment.

sp.speaker: Dinge'm.
sp.l: That's my office.
The consort's ready.

sp.speaker: Tradewell.
sp.l: And the god of pleasure
Mr. Luke our Comus enters.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: Set your face in order,
I will prepare him. Live I to see this day,
And to acknowledge you my royal master?

sp.speaker: Tradewell.
sp.l: Let the iron chests fly open, and the gold
Rusty for want of use appear again.

sp.speaker: Gettall.
sp.l: Make my ordinary flourish.

sp.speaker: Shave'm.
sp.l: Welcome, sir,
To your own palace.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: Kiss your Cleopatra,
And show yourself in your magnificent bounties
A second Anthony.

sp.speaker: Dinge'm.
sp.l: All the nine worthies.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.l: Variety of pleasures wait on you.
And a strong back.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Give me leave to breath, I pray you.
I am astonished! all this preparation
for me? and this choice modest beauty wrought
To feed my appetite.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We are all your creatures.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: A house well furnished.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: At your own cost, sir.
Glad I the instrument. I prophesied
You should possess what now you do, and therefore
Prepared it for your pleasure. There's no rag
This Venus wears, but on my knowledge was
Derived from your brother's cash. The lease of the house
And furniture, cost near a thousand, sir.

sp.speaker: Shave'm.
sp.l: But now you are master both of it and me.
I hope you'll build elsewhere.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: And see you placed
Fair one to your desert. As I live, friend Tradewell,
I hardly knew you, your clothes so well become you.
What is your loss; speak truth?

sp.speaker: Gettall.
sp.l: But on a new supply he shall recover
The sum told twenty times o'er.

sp.speaker: Shau'm.
sp.l: There is a banquet,
And after that a soft couch that attends you.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: I couple not in the daylight. Expectation
Heightens the pleasure of the night, my sweet one
Your music's harsh, discharge it: I have provided
A better comfort, and you shall frolic it
In another place.

sp.speaker: Goldw.
sp.l: But have you brought gold, and store sir?

sp.speaker: Tradew.
sp.l: I long to wear the caster.

sp.speaker: Goldw.
sp.l: I to appear
In a fresh habit.

sp.speaker: Shave'm.
sp.l: My mercer and my silkman
Waited me two hours since.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: I am no porter
To carry so much gold as will supply
Your vast desires, but I have taken order for you,
You shall have what is fitting, and they come here will see it performed. Do your offices: you have
My lord chief justices warrant for't.

sp.speaker: Sheriff.
sp.l: Seize 'em all.

sp.speaker: Shave'm.
sp.l: The city-marshal!

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: And the sheriff. I know him.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.l: We are betrayed.

sp.speaker: Dinge'm.
sp.l: Undone.

sp.speaker: Gettall.
sp.l: Dear m. Luke.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: You cannot be so cruel: your persuasion
Chid us into these courses, oft repeating,
Show yourselves city-sparks, and hang up money.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: True, when it was my brothers I contemned it,
But now it is mine own, the case is altered.

sp.speaker: Tradewel.
sp.l: Will you prove yourself a devil? tempt us to mischief,
And then discover it.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Argue that hereafter.
In the mean time, m. Goldwire, you that made
Your ten pound suppers; kept your punks at livery
In Brainford, Stanes, and Barnet; and this in London.
Held correspondence with your fellow-cashers,
Ka me, ka thee; and knew in your accompis
To cheat my brother, if you can evade me,
If there be law in London your father's bonds
Shall answer for what you are out.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: You often told us
It was a bugbear.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Such a one as shall fright 'em
Out of their estates to make me satisfaction,
To the utmost scruple. And for you madam,
My Cleopatra, by your own confession
Your house, and all your movables are mine;
Nor shall you, nor your matron need to trouble
Your mercer, or your silkman; a blue gown,
And a whip to boot, as I will handle it
Will serve the turn in Bridewell, and these soft hands,
When they are enured to beating hemp, be scoured
in your penitent tears, and quite forget
Powders, and bitter almonds.

sp.speaker: Shavem, secret, Dingem.
sp.l: Will you show no mercy?

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: I am inexorable.

sp.speaker: Gettall.
sp.l: I'll make bold
To take my leave, the gamesters stay my coming.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: We must not part so, gentle m. Gettal.
Your box, your certain income, must pay back
Three hundred as I take it, or you lie by it.
There's half a million stirring in your house,
This a poor trifle, Mr. sheriff, and m. Marshal
On your perils do your offices.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: Dost thou cry now
Like a maudlin gamester after loss? I'll suffer
Like a roman, and now in my misery,
In scorn of all thy wealth, to thy teeth tell thee
Thou were't my pander.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Shall I hear this from
My prentice?

sp.speaker: Marshal.
sp.l: Stop his mouth.

sp.speaker: Sheriff.
sp.l: Away with 'em. Exeunt sheriff, marshal, and the rest

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: A prosperous omen in my entrance to
My altered nature. These house-thiefs removed,
And what was lost, beyond my hopes recovered,
Will add unto my heap. Increase of wealth
Is the rich man's ambition, and mine
Shall know no bounds. The valiant Macedon
Having in his conceit subdued one world,
Lamented that there were no more to conquer: in my way he shall be my great example.
And when my private house in crammed abundance
Shall prove the chamber of the city poor,
And Genoese banquers shall look pale with envy
When I am mentioned, I shall grieve there is
No more to be exhausted in one kingdom.
Religion, conscience, charity, farewell.
To me you are words only, and no more,
All humane happiness consists in store.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: A t m. Luke's suit? the action twenty thousand?

sp.speaker: 1 sergeant.
sp.l: With two or three executions, which shall grind
You to powder when we have you in the counter.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: Thou dost belie him varlet. He, good gentleman,
Will weep when he hears how we are used.

sp.speaker: 1 Serjeant.
sp.l: Yes millstones.

sp.speaker: Penury.
sp.l: He promised to lend me ten pound for a bargain,
He will not do it this way.

sp.speaker: 2 sergeant.
sp.l: I have warrant
For what I have done. You are a poor fellow,
And there being little to be got by you,
In charity, as I am an officer,
I would not have seen you, but upon compulsion,
And for mine own security.

sp.speaker: 3 sergeant.
sp.l: You are a gallant,
And I do you a courtesy; provided
That you have money. For a piece an hour
I'll keep you in the house, till you send for bail.

sp.speaker: 2 sergeant.
sp.l: In the mean time yeoman run to the other counter,
And search if there be ought else out against him.

sp.speaker: 3 segeant.
sp.l: That done, haste to his creditors. He's a prize,
And as we are city pirates by our oaths,
We must make the best on't.

sp.speaker: Hoyst.
sp.l: Do your worst, I care not.
I'll be removed to the fleet, and drink and drab there
In spite of your teeth. I now repent I ever
Intended to be honest

sp.speaker: 3 sergeant.
sp.l: Here he comes
You had best tell so.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: Worshipful sir,
you come in time to free us from these bandogs.
I know you gave no way to't.

sp.speaker: Penury.
sp.l: Or if you did,
'T was but to try our patience.

sp.speaker: Hoyst.
sp.l: I must tell you
I do not like such trials.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Are you sergeants
Acquainted with the danger of a rescue,
Yet stand here prating in the street. The counter
Is a safer place to parley in.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: Are you in earnest?

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Y s faith, I will be satisfied to a token,
Or build upon't you rot there.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: Can a gentleman,
Of your soft and silken temper, speak such language?

sp.speaker: Penury.
sp.l: So honest, so religious.

sp.speaker: Hoyst.
sp.l: That preached
So much of charity for us to your brother?

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Yes when I was in poverty it showed well,
But I inherit with his state, his mind,
And rougher nature. I grant, than I talked
For some ends to myself concealed, of pity,
The poor man's orisons; and such like nothing.
But what I thought you all shall feel, and with rigor.
Kind m. Luke says it. who pays for your attendance?
Do you wait gratis?

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: Hear us speak.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: While I,
Like the adder stop mine ears. Or did I listen,
Though you spoke with the tongues of angels to me
I am not to be altered.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: Let me make the best
Of my ships, and their freight.

sp.speaker: Penury.
sp.l: Lend me the ten pounds you promised.

sp.speaker: Hoyst.
sp.l: A day or two's patience to redeem my mortgage,
And you shall be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: To the utmost farthing.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: I'll show some mercy; which is, that I will not
torture you with false hopes, but make you know
What you shall trust to. Your ships to my use
Are seized on. I have got into my hands
Your bargains from the sailor, 'twas a good one
For such a petty sum. I will likewise take
The extremity of your mortgage, and the forfeit:
Of your several bonds, the use, and principle
Shall not serve. Think of the basket, wretches,
And a coal-sack for a winding-sheet.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: Broker.

sp.speaker: Hoyst.
sp.l: Jew.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: Imposer.

sp.speaker: Hoyst.
sp.l: Cutthroat.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: Hypocrite.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Do, rail on.
Move mountains with your breath, it shakes not me,

sp.speaker: Penury.
sp.l: On my knees I beg compassion my wife and children
Shall hourly pray for your worship.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: Mine betake thee
To the devil thy tutor.

sp.speaker: Penury.
sp.l: Look upon my tears.

sp.speaker: Hoyst.
sp.l: My rage.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: My wrongs.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: They are all a like to me.
Entreats, curses, prayers, or imprecations.
Do your duties sergeants, I am else where looked for.

sp.speaker: 3. Segeant.
sp.l: This your kind creditor?

sp.speaker: 2. Segeant.
sp.l: A vast villain rather.

sp.speaker: Penury.
sp.l: See, see, the sergeants pity us. Yet he's marble.

sp.speaker: Hoist.
sp.l: Buried alive!

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: There's no means to avoid it.

sp.speaker: Stargaze.
sp.l: Not wait upon my lady?

sp.speaker: Holafast.
sp.l: Nor come at her,
You find it not in your almanac.

sp.speaker: Milliscent.
sp.l: Nor I have licence
To bring her breakfast.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.l: My new master hath
Decreed this for a fasting day. She hath feasted long
And after a carnival lent ever follows.

sp.speaker: Milliscent.
sp.l: Give me the key of her wardrobe. You'll repent this:
I must know what gown she'll wear;

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.l: You are mistaken,
Dame president of the sweet meats. she and her daughters
Are turned philosophers, and must carry all.
Their wealth about 'em. They have clothes laid in their chamber,
If they please to put 'em on, and without help too,
Or they may walk naked. You look m. Stargaze
As you had seen a strange comet, and had now foretold,
The end of the world, and on what day. And you,
As the wasps had broke into the galley-pots,
And eaten up your apricots.

sp.speaker: Within lady.
sp.l: Stargaze. Milliscent.

sp.speaker: Milliscent.
sp.l: My lady's voice.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.l: Stir not, you are confined here.
Your ladyship may approach them if you please,
But they are bound in this circle.

sp.speaker: Within lady.
sp.l: Mine own bees
Rebel against me. When my kind brother knows this
I will be so revenged.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.l: The world's well altered.
He's your kind brother now. but yesterday
Your slave and jesting-stock.

sp.stage: Enter lady, Anne, marry, in course habit weeping.

sp.speaker: Milliscent.
sp.l: What witch hath transformed you?

sp.speaker: Starg.
sp.l: Is this the glorious shape your cheating brother
Premised you should appear in?

sp.speaker: Milliscent.
sp.l: My young ladies
In buffin gowns, and green aprons! tear 'em off,
Rather show all then be seen thus.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.l: 'Tis more comely
I wis then their other whim-whams.

sp.speaker: Millis.
sp.l: A French hood too;
Now 'tis out of fashion, a fool's cap would show better

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: We are fooled indeed, by whose command are we used thus?

sp.speaker: Holdf.
sp.l: Here he comes that can best resolve you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: O good brother!
Do you thus preserve your protestation to me?
Can Queens envy this habit? or did Juno
E'er feast in such a shape?

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: You talked of Hebe,
Of Iris, and I know not what; but were they
Dressed as we are; they were sure some chandler's daughters
Bleaching linen in Moorfields.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Or exchange-wenches,
Coming from eating pudding-pies on a Sunday
At Pemlico, or Islington.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Save you sister.
I now dare style you so: you were before
Too glorious to be looked on; now you appear
Like a city matron, and my pretty nieces
Such things as were born, and bred there. Why should you ape
The fashions of court-ladies? whose high titles
And pedigrees of long descent, give warrant
For their superfluous bravery? 'twas monstrous:
Till now you never looked lovely.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Is this spoken
In scorn?

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Fie, no, with judgement. I make good
my promise, and now show you like yourselves ,
In your own natural shapes, and stand resolved
You shall continue so.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: It is confessed sir.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Sir! Sirrah. Use your old phrase, I can bear it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: That if you please forgotten. We acknowledge
We have deserved ill from you, yet despair not;
Though we are at your disposure, you'll maintain us
Like your brother's wife, and daughters.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: 'Tis my purpose.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: And not make us ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Admired rather,
As fair examples for our proud city dames,
And their proud brood to imitate: do not frown
If you do, I laugh, and glory that I have
The power in you to scourge a general vice,
And rise up a new satirist: but hear gently,
And in a gentle phrase I'll reprehend
Your late disguised deformity, and cry up
This decency, and neatness, with th'advantage
You shall receive by 't.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: We are bound to hear you.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: With a soul inclined to learn. Your father was
An honest country farmer. Goodman humble,
By his neighbours never called master. Did your pride
Descend from him? but let that pass: your fortune,
Or rather your husband's industry, advanced you
To the rank of a merchant's wife. He made a knight,
And your sweet mistress-ship, ladyfied; you wore
Satin on solemn days, a chain of gold,
A velvet hood, rich borders, and sometimes
A dainty miniver cap, a silver pin
Headed with a pearl worth threepence, and thus far
You were privileged, and no man envied it,
It being for the city's honour, that
There should be a distinction between
The wife of a patrician, and plebeian.

sp.speaker: Millis.
sp.l: Pray you leave preaching, or choose some other text;
your rhetoric is too moving, for it makes
Your auditory weep.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Peace, chattering magpie,
I'll treat of you anon: but when the height
And dignity of London's blessings grew
Contemptible, and the name lady Maioress
Became a byword, and you scorned the means
By which you were raised, my brother's fond indulgence
Giving the reigns to't; and no object pleased you
But the glittering pomp, and bravery of the court.
What a strange, nay monstrous metamorphosis followed!
No English workman then could please your fancy;
The French, and Tuscan dress your whole discourse;
This bawd to prodigality entertained
To buzz into your ears, what shape this countess
Appeared in the last mask; and how it drew
The young lords eyes upon her; and this usher
Succeeded in the eldest prentices place
To walk before you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Pray you end.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.l: Proceed sir,
I could fast almost a prenticeship to hear you.
You touch 'em so to the quick.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Then as I said,
The reverend hood cast off, your borrowed hair
Powdered, and curled, was by your dressers art
Formed like a coronet, hanged with diamonds,
And the richest orient pearl: your carkanets
That did adorn your neck of equal value:
Your Hungerland bands, and Spanish quellio russes:
Great lords and ladies feasted to survey
Embroidered petticoats: and sickness feigned
That your night rails of forty pounds a piece
Might be seen with envy of the visitants;
Rich pantables in ostentation shown,
And roses worth a family; you were served in plate;
Stirred not a foot without your coach. And going
To church not for devotion, but to show
Your pomp, you were tickled when the beggars cried
heaven save your honour, this idolatry
Paid to a painted room.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.l: Nay, you have reason
To blubber all of you

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: And when you lay
In child bed, at the christening of this minx,
I well remember it, as you had been
An absolute Princess, since they have no more,
Three several chambers hung. The first with arras,
And that for waiters; the second crimson satin
For the meaner sort of guests; the third of scarlet,
Of the rich Tyrian die; a canopy
To cover the brats cradle: you in state
Like Pompie's Julia.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: No more I pray you.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Of this be sure you shall not. I'll cut off
Whatever is exorbitant in you,
Or in your daughters, and reduce you to
Your natural forms, and habits: not in revenge
Of your base usage of me, but to fright
Others by your example: 'tis decreed
You shall serve one another, for I will
Allow no waiter to you. Out of doors
With these useless drones,
sp.stage: Whilst the act plays, the footstep, little table, and arras hung up for the musicians.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.l: Will you pack?

sp.speaker: Milliscent.
sp.l: Not till I have
My trunks along with me.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Not a rag, you came
Hither without a box.

sp.speaker: Stargaze.
sp.l: You'll show to me
I hope sir more compassion.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.l: 'Troth I'll be
Thus far a suitor for him. He hath printed
An almanac for this year at his own charge,
Let him have th'impression with him to set up with.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: For once I'll be entreated: let it be
Thrown to him out of the window.

sp.speaker: Stargaze.
sp.l: O cursed stars
that reigned at my nativity! how have you cheated
Your poor observer.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Must we part in tears?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Farewell, good Milliscent.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I am sick, and meet with
A rough physician. O my pride! and scorn!
How justly am I punished!

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Now we suffer
For our stubbornness and disobedience
To our good father.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: And the base conditions,
We imposed upon our suitors.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Get you in,
And caterwaul in a corner.
sp.stage: Lady, Anne, Marry, go off at one door; Stargaze and Millisc. at the other.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: There's no contending.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: How likest thou my carriage, holdfast?

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.l: Well in some part,
But it relishes I know not how, a little
Of too much tyranny.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Thou art a fool:
He's cruel to himself, that dares not be
Severe to those that used him cruelly.

sp.stage: Enter Luke, sir John, Lacy and Plenty.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: You care not then, as it seems, to be converted
To our religion.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: We know no such word,
Nor power but the devil, and him we serve for fear,
Not love.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: I am glad that charge is saved.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: We put
That trick upon your brother, to have means
to come to the city. Now to you we'll discover
The close design that brought us, with assurance
If you lend your aids to furnish us with that
Which in the colony was not to be purchased,
No merchant ever made such a return
For his most precious venture, as you shall
Receive from us; far, far, above your hopes,
Or fancy to imagine.
sp.stage: Musicians come down to make ready for the song at Aras.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: It must be
Some strange commodity, and of a dear value,
(Such an opinion is planted in me,
You will deal fairly) that I would not hazard.
Give me the name of't.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: I fear you will make
Some scruple in your conscience to grant it.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Conscience! No, no; so it may be done with safety,
And without danger of the law.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: For that
You shall sleep securely. Nor shall it diminish,
But add unto your heap such an increase,
As what you now possess shall appear an atom
To the mountain it brings with it.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Do not rack me
With expectation.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Thus then in a word:
The devil. Why start you at his name? if you
Desire to wallow in wealth and worldly honours,
You must make haste to be familiar with him.
This devil, whose priest I am, and by him made
A deep magician (For I can do wonders)
Appeared to me in Virginia, and commanded
With many stripes (For that's his cruel custom)
I should provide on pain of his fierce wrath
Against the next great sacrifice, at which
We grovelling on our faces, fall before him,
Two Christian virgins, that with their pure blood
Might die his horrid altars, and a third
(In his hate to such embraces as are lawful)
married, and with your ceremonious rites
As an oblation unto Hecate,
And wanton lust her favourite.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: A devilish custom:
And yet why should it startle me? there are
Enough of the sex fit fort his use: but virgins,
And such a matron as you speak of, hardly to be wrought to it.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: A mine of gold for a fee
Waits him that undertakes it, and performs it.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: Know you no distressed widow, or poor
Maids, whose want of dower, though well born,
Makes 'em weary of their own country?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Such as had rather be
Miserable in another world, then where
They have surfeited in felicity?

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Give me leave,
I would not lose this purchase. A grave matron!
And two pure virgins. Umph! I think my sister
Though proud was ever honest; and my nieces
Untainted yet. Why should not they be shipped
For this employment? they are burden some to me,
And eat too much. And if they stay in London,
They will find friends that to my loss will force me
To composition. 'twere a masterpiece
If this could be effected. They were ever
Ambitious of title. Should I urge
Matching with these they shall live Indian Queens,
It may do much. But what shall I feel here,
Knowing to what they are designed? They absent,
The thought of them will leave me. It shall be so.
I'll furnish you, and to endear the service
In mine own family, and my blood too.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Make this good, and your house shall not
Contain the gold we'll send you.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: You have seen my sister, and my two nieces?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: These persuaded
how happily they shall live, and in what pomp
When they are in your kingdoms, for you must
Work 'em a belief that you are Kings.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: We are so.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: I'll put it in practice instantly. Study you
For moving language. Sister, nieces. how
Still mourning? dry your eyes, and clear these clouds
That do obscure your beauties. Did you believe
My personated reprehension; though
It showed like a rough anger, could be serious?
Forget the fright I put you in. My ends
In humbling you was, to set off the height
Of honour, principle honour, which my studies
When you least expect it shall confer upon you.
Still you seem doubtful: be not wanting to
Yourselves , nor let the strangeness of the means,
With the shadow of some danger, render you
Incredulous.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Our usage hath been such,
As we can faintly hope that your intents,
And language are the same.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: I'll change those hopes
To certainties.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: With what art he winds about them!

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: What will you say? or what thanks shall I look for?
If now I raise you to such eminence, as
The wife, and daughters of a citizen
Never arrived at. Many for their wealth (I grant)
Have written ladies of honour, and some few
Have higher titles, and that's the farthest rise
You can in England hope for. What think you
If I should mark you out a way to live
Queens in another climate?
sp.stage: The banquets ready. One chair, and wine.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: We desire
A competence.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: And prefer our country's smoke
Before outlandish fire.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: But should we listen
To such impossibilities, 'tis not in
The power of man to make it good.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: I'll do't.
Nor is this seat of majesty far removed.
It is but to Virginia.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: How, Virginia!
High heaven forbid. Remember sir, I beseech you,
What creatures are shipped thither.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Condemned wretches,
Forfeited to the law.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Strumpets and bawds,
For the abomination of their life,
Spewed out of their own country.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Your false fears
Abuse my noble purposes. Such indeed
Are sent as slaves to labour there, but you
To absolute sovereignty. Observe these men,
With reverence observe them. They are Kings,
Kings of such spacious territories, and dominions:
As our great Britain measured, will appear
A garden to't.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: You shall be adored there
As goddesses.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Your litters made of gold
Supported by your vassals, proud to bear
The burden on their shoulders.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: Pomp, and ease,
With delicates that Europe never knew,
Like pages shall wait on you.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: If you have minds
To entertain the greatness offered to you,
With outstretched arms, and willing hands embrace it.
But this refused, imagine what can make you
Most miserable here, and rest assured,
In storms it falls upon you: take 'em in,
And use your best persuasion. If that fail.
I'll send 'em aboard in a dry fat.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Be not moved sir.
We'll work 'em to your will: yet ere we part,
Your worldly cares deferred, a little mirth
Would not misbecome us.
sp.stage: Exeunt Lacy. Plenty, lady, Ann, Marry.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: You say well. And now
It coms into my memory, this is my birthday,
Which with solemnity I would observe,
But that it would ask cost.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: That shall not grieve you.
By my art I will prepare you such a feast,
As Persia in her height of pomp, and riot
Did never equal: and ravishing music
As the Italian princes seldom heard
At their greatest entertainments. Name your guests.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: I must have none.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Not the city senate?

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: No.
Nor yet poor neighbours. The first would argue me
Of foolish ostentation, the latter
Of too much hospitality, and a virtue
Grown obsolete, and useless. I will sit
Alone, and surfeit in my store, while others
With envy pine at it. My genius pampered
With the thought of what I am, and what they suffer
I have marked out to misery.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: You shall;
And something I will add, you yet conceive not,
Nor will I be slow-paced.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: I have one business,
And that dispatched I am free.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: About it sir,
Leave the rest to me.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Till now I never loved magic.

sp.stage: Enter lord, old Goldwire, and old Tradewell.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Believe me, gentlemen! I never was
So cozened in a fellow. He disguised
Hypocrisy in such a cunning shape
Of real goodness, that I would have sworn
This devil a saint. M. Goldwire, and m. Tradewell,
What do you mean to do? put on.

sp.speaker: Old Goldwire.
sp.l: With your lordship's favour.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: I'll have it so.

sp.speaker: Old Tradew.
sp.l: Your will, my lord, excuses
The rudeness of our manners.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: You have received
Penitent letters from your sons I doubt not?

sp.speaker: Old Tradew.
sp.l: They are our only sons.

sp.speaker: Old Goldw.
sp.l: And as we are fathers,
Remembering the errors of our youth,
We would pardon slips in them.

sp.speaker: Old Tradewell.
sp.l: And pay for 'em
In a moderate way.

sp.speaker: Old Goldw.
sp.l: In which we hope your lordship
Will be our mediator.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: All my power,
You freely shall command. 'tis he! you are well met.
And to my wish. And wondrous brave,
Your habit speaks you a merchant royal.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: What I wear, I take not upon trust.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Your betters may, and blush not for't.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: If you have naught else with me
But to argue that, I will make bold to leave you.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: You are very peremptory, pray you stay.
I once held you an upright honest man.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: I am honester now
by a hundred thousand pound, I thank my stars for't,
Upon the exchange, and if your late opinion
Be altered, who can help it? good my lord
To the point. I have other business then to talk
Of honesty, and opinions.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Yet you may
Do well, if you please, to show the one, and merit
The other from good men, in a case that now
Is offered to you.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: What is't? I am troubled.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Here are two gentlemen, the fathers of
Your brother's prentices.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Mine, my lord, I take it.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Mr. Goldwire, and Mr. Tradewell.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: They are welcome, if
They come prepared to satisfy the damage
I have sustained by their sons.

sp.speaker: Old Goldw.
sp.l: We are, so you please
To use a conscience.

sp.speaker: Old Tradew.
sp.l: Which we hope you will do,
For your own worship's sake.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Conscience, my friends,
And wealth are not always neighbours. Should I part
With what the law gives me, I should suffer mainly
In my reputation. For it would convince me
Of indiscretion. Nor will you I hope move me
To do myself such prejudice.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: No moderation.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: They cannot look for't, and preserve in
Me a thriving citizens credit. Your bonds lie
For your son's truth, and they shall answer all
They have run out. The masters never prospered
Since gentlemen's sons grew prentices. When we look
To have our business done at home, they are
Abroad in the tennis-court, or in Partridge-alley,
In Lambeth marsh, or a cheating ordinary
Where I found your sons. I have your bonds, look to't.
A thousand pounds a piece, and that will hardly
Repair my losses.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Thou dar'st not show thyself
Such a devil.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Good words.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Such a cutthroat. I have heard of
The usage of your brother's wife, and daughters.
You shall find you are not lawless, and that your
Moneys cannot justify your villainies.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: I endure this.
And good my lord, now you talk in time of moneys,
Pay in what you owe me. And give me leave to wonder
Your wisdom should have leisure to consider
The business of these gentlemen, or my carriage
To my sister, or my nieces, being yourself
So much in my danger.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: In thy danger?

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Mine.
I find in my counting house a manor pawned,
Pawned, my good lord, Lacie-mannour, and that manor
From which you have the title of a lord,
And it please your good lordship. You are a noble man
Pray you pay in my moneys. The interest
Will eat faster in't, then aqua fortis in iron.
Now though you bear me hard, I love your lordship.
I grant your person to be privileged
From all arrests. Yet there lives a foolish creature
Called an undersheriff, who being well paid, will serve
Au extent on lord's , or lowns land. Pay it in,
I would be loath your name should sink. Or that
Your hopeful son, when he returns from travel,
Should find you my lord without land. You are angry
For my good counsel. Look you to your bonds: had I known
Of your coming, believe it I would have had sergeants ready:
Lord how you fret! but that a tavern's near
You should taste a cup of muscadine in my house,
To wash down sorrow, but there it will do better,
I know you'll drink a health to me.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: To thy damnation.
Was there ever such a villain! Heaven forgive me
For speaking so unchristianly, though he deserves it.

sp.speaker: Old Goldm.
sp.l: We are undone.

sp.speaker: Old tradem.
sp.l: Our families quite ruined.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Take courage gentlemen. Comfort may appear.
And punishment overtake him, when he least expects it.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Be silent on your life.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.l: I am overjoyed.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Are the pictures placed as I directed?

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: And the musicians ready?

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.l: All is done
As you commanded.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Make haste, and be careful,
You know your cue, and postures.

sp.speaker: Plenty within.
sp.l: We are perfect.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: 'Tis well: the rest are come too?

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.l: And disposed of
To your own wish.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Set forth the table. So.
sp.stage: Enter servants with a rich banquet.
sp.l: A perfect banquet. At the upper end,
His chair in state, he shall feast like a prince.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.l: And rise like a Dutch hangman.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Not a word more.
How like you the preparation? fill your room,
And taste the cates, then in your thought consider
A rich man, that lives wisely to himself,
In his full height of glory.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: I can brook
No rival in this happiness. How sweetly
These dainties, when unpaid for, please my palate!
Some wine. Jove's nectar. Brightness to the star
That governed at my birth shoot down thy influence,
And with a perpetuity of being
Continue this felicity, not gained
By vows to saints above, and much less purchased
By the thriving industry; nor fallen upon me
As a reward to piety, and religion,
Or service for my country. I owe all this
To dissimulation, and the shape
I wore of goodness. Let my brother number
His beads devoutly, and believe his alms
To beggars, his compassion to his debtors,
Will wing his better part, disrobed of flesh,
To soar above the firmament. I am well,
And so I surfeit here in all abundance;
Though styled a cormorant, a cutthroat, Jew,
And prosecuted with the fatal curses
Of widows, undone orphans, and what else
Such as malign my state can load me with,
I will not envy it. You promised music?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: And you shall hear the strength and power
Of it, the spirit of Orpheus raised to make it good,
And in those ravishing strains with which he moved
Charon and Cerberus to give him way
To fetch from hell his lost Eurydice,
Appear swifter than thought.
sp.stage: Music. At one door Cerberus, at the other, Charon, Orpheus, chorus.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: 'Tis wondrous strange.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Does not the object and the accent take you?

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: A pretty fable. But that music should
Alter in friends their nature, is to me
Impossible. Since in myself I find
What I have once decreed, shall know no change.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: You are constant to your purposes, yet I think
that I could stagger you.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Should I present
Your servants, debtors, and the rest that suffer
By your fit severity, I presume the sight
Would move you to compassion.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Not a mote.
The music that your Orpheus made, was harsh
To the delight I should receive in hearing
Their cries, and groans, if it be in your power
I would now see 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Spirits in their shapes
Shall show them as they are. But if it should move you?

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: If it do. May I never find pity.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Be your own judge.
Appear as I commanded.
sp.stage: Sad music. Enter Goldwire, and Tradewell as from prison. Fortune, Hoyst, penury following after them. Shavem in a blue gown, secret, Dingem, old Tradewell, and old Goldwire with sergeants. As erected they all kneel to Luke, heaving up their hands for mercy. Stargaze with a pack of alminacks, Milliscent.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha!
This move me to compassion? or raise
One sign of seeming pity in my face?
You are deceived: it rather renders me more flinty, and obdurate. A South wind
Shall sooner soften marble, and the rain
That slides down gently from his flaggy wings
O'erflow the Alps: then knees, or tears, or groans
Shall wrest compunction from me. 'tis my glory
That they are wretched, and by me made so,
It sets my happiness off. I could not triumph
If these were not my captives. Ha! my tarriers
As it appears have seized on these old foxes,
As I gave order. New addition to
my scene of mirth. Ha, ha! They now grow tedious
Let 'em be removed, some other object. If
Your art can show it.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: You shall perceive 'tis boundless.
Yet one thing real if you please?

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: What is it?

sp.speaker: S. Jo.
sp.l: Your nieces ere they put to sea, crave humbly
Though absent in their bodies, they may take leave
Of their late suitors statues.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: There they hang,
In things different I am tractable.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: There pay your vows you have liberty.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: O sweet figure
Of my abused Lacy! when removed
Into another world; I'll daily pay
A sacrifice of sight, to thy remembrance;
And with a shower of tears strive to wash of
The stain of that contempt, my foolish pride,
And insolence threw upon thee.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: I had been
Too happy, if I had enjoyed the substance,
But far unworthy of it, now I shall
Thus prostrate to thy statue.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: My kind husband,
Blessed in my misery, from the monastery
To which my disobedience confined thee,
With thy souls eye, which distance cannot hinder,
Look on my penitence. O that I could
Call back time past, thy holy vow dispensed,
With what humility would I observe
My long neglected duty.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Does not this move you?

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Yes as they do the statues, and her sorrow
My absent brother. If by your magic art
You can give life to these, or bring him hither
To witness her repentance, I may have
Perchance some feeling of it.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: For your sport
You shall see a masterpiece. Here's nothing but
A superficies, colours, and no substance.
Sit still, and to your wonder, and amazement
I'll give these organs. This the sacrifice
To make the great work perfect.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Prodigious.

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.l: Nay they have life, and motion. Descend.
And for your absent brother. This washed off
Against your will you shall know him.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: I am lost.
Guilt strikes me dumb.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: You have seen my lord the pageant.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: I have, and am ravished with it.

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.l: What think you now
Of this clear soul? this honest pious man?
Have I stripped him bare. Or will your lordship have
A farther trial of him? 'tis not in a wolf to change his nature.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: I long since confessed my errors

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.l: Look up, I forgive you,
And seal your pardons thus.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I am too full
Of joy to speak it.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: I am another creature,
Not what I was.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: I vow to show myself
When I am married, an humble wife,
Not a commanding mistress.

sp.speaker: Plenty.
sp.l: On those terms
I gladly thus embrace you.

sp.speaker: Lacte.
sp.l: Welcome to
My bosom. As the one half of myself,
I'll love you, and cherish you.

sp.speaker: Goldwire.
sp.l: Mercv

sp.speaker: Tradewell and the rest.
sp.l: Good sir mercy.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: This day is sacred to it. All shall find me
As far as lawful pity can give way to't,
Indulgent to your wishes, though with loss
Unto myself. My kind, and honest brother,
Looking into yourself, have you seen the Gorgon?
What a golden dream you have had in the possession
Of my estate? but here's a revocation
That wakes you out of it. Monster in nature
Revengeful, avaritious atheist,
Transcending all example. But I shall be
A sharer in thy crimes, should I repeat 'em.
What wilt thou do? Turn hypocrite again,
With hope dissimulation can aid thee?
Or that one eye will shed a tear in sign
Of sorrow for thee? I have warrant to
Make bold with mine own, pray you uncase. This key too
I must make bold with. Hide thyself in some desert,
Where good men ne'er may find thee: or in justice
Pack to Virginia, and repent. Not for
Those horrid ends to which thou didst design these.

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: I care not where I go, what's done with words
Cannot be undone.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Yet sir, show some mercy;
Because his cruelty to me, and mine,
Did good upon us.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Of that at better leisure,
As his penitency shall work me. Make you good
Your promised reformation, and mistrust
Our city dames, whom wealth makes proud, to move
In their own spheres, and willingly to confess
In their habits, manners, and their highest port,
A distance 'twixt the city, and the court.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
